        "$:/core/macros/toc": {
            "title": "$:/core/macros/toc",
            "tags": "$:/tags/Macro",
            "text": "\\define toc-caption()\n<$set name=\"tv-wikilinks\" value=\"no\">\n  <$transclude field=\"caption\">\n    <$view field=\"title\"/>\n  </$transclude>\n</$set>\n\\end\n\n\\define toc-body(tag,sort:\"\",itemClassFilter,exclude,path)\n<ol class=\"tc-toc\">\n  <$list filter=\"\"\"[all[shadows+tiddlers]tag<__tag__>!has[draft.of]$sort$] -[<__tag__>] -[enlist<__exclude__>]\"\"\">\n    <$vars item=<<currentTiddler>> path={{{ [<__path__>addsuffix[/]addsuffix<__tag__>] }}}>\n      <$set name=\"excluded\" filter=\"\"\"[enlist<__exclude__>] [<__tag__>]\"\"\">\n        <$set name=\"toc-item-class\" filter=<<__itemClassFilter__>> emptyValue=\"toc-item-selected\" value=\"toc-item\">\n          <li class=<<toc-item-class>>>\n            <$list filter=\"[all[current]toc-link[no]]\" emptyMessage=\"<$link><$view field='caption'><$view field='title'/></$view></$link>\">\n              <<toc-caption>>\n            </$list>\n            <$macrocall $name=\"toc-body\" tag=<<item>> sort=<<__sort__>> itemClassFilter=<<__itemClassFilter__>> exclude=<<excluded>> path=<<path>>/>\n          </li>\n        </$set>\n      </$set>\n    </$vars>\n  </$list>\n</ol>\n\\end\n\n\\define toc(tag,sort:\"\",itemClassFilter:\"\")\n<$macrocall $name=\"toc-body\"  tag=<<__tag__>> sort=<<__sort__>> itemClassFilter=<<__itemClassFilter__>> />\n\\end\n\n\\define toc-linked-expandable-body(tag,sort:\"\",itemClassFilter,exclude,path)\n<!-- helper function -->\n<$qualify name=\"toc-state\" title={{{ [[$:/state/toc]addsuffix<__path__>addsuffix[-]addsuffix<currentTiddler>] }}}>\n  <$set name=\"toc-item-class\" filter=<<__itemClassFilter__>> emptyValue=\"toc-item-selected\" value=\"toc-item\">\n    <li class=<<toc-item-class>>>\n    <$link>\n      <$reveal type=\"nomatch\" stateTitle=<<toc-state>> text=\"open\">\n        <$button setTitle=<<toc-state>> setTo=\"open\" class=\"tc-btn-invisible tc-popup-keep\">\n          {{$:/core/images/right-arrow}}\n        </$button>\n      </$reveal>\n      <$reveal type=\"match\" stateTitle=<<toc-state>> text=\"open\">\n        <$button setTitle=<<toc-state>> setTo=\"close\" class=\"tc-btn-invisible tc-popup-keep\">\n          {{$:/core/images/down-arrow}}\n        </$button>\n      </$reveal>\n      <<toc-caption>>\n    </$link>\n    <$reveal type=\"match\" stateTitle=<<toc-state>> text=\"open\">\n      <$macrocall $name=\"toc-expandable\" tag=<<currentTiddler>> sort=<<__sort__>> itemClassFilter=<<__itemClassFilter__>> exclude=<<__exclude__>> path=<<__path__>>/>\n    </$reveal>\n    </li>\n  </$set>\n</$qualify>\n\\end\n\n\\define toc-unlinked-expandable-body(tag,sort:\"\",itemClassFilter,exclude,path)\n<!-- helper function -->\n<$qualify name=\"toc-state\" title={{{ [[$:/state/toc]addsuffix<__path__>addsuffix[-]addsuffix<currentTiddler>] }}}>\n  <$set name=\"toc-item-class\" filter=<<__itemClassFilter__>> emptyValue=\"toc-item-selected\" value=\"toc-item\">\n    <li class=<<toc-item-class>>>\n      <$reveal type=\"nomatch\" stateTitle=<<toc-state>> text=\"open\">\n        <$button setTitle=<<toc-state>> setTo=\"open\" class=\"tc-btn-invisible tc-popup-keep\">\n          {{$:/core/images/right-arrow}}\n          <<toc-caption>>\n        </$button>\n      </$reveal>\n      <$reveal type=\"match\" stateTitle=<<toc-state>> text=\"open\">\n        <$button setTitle=<<toc-state>> setTo=\"close\" class=\"tc-btn-invisible tc-popup-keep\">\n          {{$:/core/images/down-arrow}}\n          <<toc-caption>>\n        </$button>\n      </$reveal>\n      <$reveal type=\"match\" stateTitle=<<toc-state>> text=\"open\">\n        <$macrocall $name=\"toc-expandable\" tag=<<currentTiddler>> sort=<<__sort__>> itemClassFilter=<<__itemClassFilter__>> exclude=<<__exclude__>> path=<<__path__>>/>\n      </$reveal>\n    </li>\n  </$set>\n</$qualify>\n\\end\n\n\\define toc-expandable-empty-message()\n<$macrocall $name=\"toc-linked-expandable-body\" tag=<<tag>> sort=<<sort>> itemClassFilter=<<itemClassFilter>> exclude=<<excluded>> path=<<path>>/>\n\\end\n\n\\define toc-expandable(tag,sort:\"\",itemClassFilter:\"\",exclude,path)\n<$vars tag=<<__tag__>> sort=<<__sort__>> itemClassFilter=<<__itemClassFilter__>> path={{{ [<__path__>addsuffix[/]addsuffix<__tag__>] }}}>\n  <$set name=\"excluded\" filter=\"\"\"[enlist<__exclude__>] [<__tag__>]\"\"\">\n    <ol class=\"tc-toc toc-expandable\">\n      <$list filter=\"\"\"[all[shadows+tiddlers]tag<__tag__>!has[draft.of]$sort$] -[<__tag__>] -[enlist<__exclude__>]\"\"\">\n        <$list filter=\"[all[current]toc-link[no]]\" emptyMessage=<<toc-expandable-empty-message>> >\n          <$macrocall $name=\"toc-unlinked-expandable-body\" tag=<<__tag__>> sort=<<__sort__>> itemClassFilter=\"\"\"itemClassFilter\"\"\" exclude=<<excluded>> path=<<path>> />\n        </$list>\n      </$list>\n    </ol>\n  </$set>\n</$vars>\n\\end\n\n\\define toc-linked-selective-expandable-body(tag,sort:\"\",itemClassFilter,exclude,path)\n<$qualify name=\"toc-state\" title={{{ [[$:/state/toc]addsuffix<__path__>addsuffix[-]addsuffix<currentTiddler>] }}}>\n  <$set name=\"toc-item-class\" filter=<<__itemClassFilter__>> emptyValue=\"toc-item-selected\" value=\"toc-item\" >\n    <li class=<<toc-item-class>>>\n      <$link>\n          <$list filter=\"[all[current]tagging[]$sort$limit[1]]\" variable=\"ignore\" emptyMessage=\"<$button class='tc-btn-invisible'>{{$:/core/images/blank}}</$button>\">\n          <$reveal type=\"nomatch\" stateTitle=<<toc-state>> text=\"open\">\n            <$button setTitle=<<toc-state>> setTo=\"open\" class=\"tc-btn-invisible tc-popup-keep\">\n              {{$:/core/images/right-arrow}}\n tc-popup-keep\">\n              {{$:/core/images/down-arrow}}\n            </$button>\n          </$reveal>\n        </$list>\n        <<toc-caption>>\n      </$link>\n      <$reveal type=\"match\" path=<<__path__>>/>\n      </$reveal>\n    </li>\n  </$set>\n</$qualify>\n\\end\n\n\\define toc-unlinked-selective-expandable-body(tag,sort:\"\",itemClassFilter,exclude,path)\n<$qualify </li>\n  </$set>\n</$qualify>\n\\end\n\n\\define toc-selective-expandable-empty-message()\n<$macrocall $name=\"toc-linked-selective-expandable-body\" tag=<<tag>> sort=<<sort>> itemClassFilter=<<itemClassFilter>> exclude=<<excluded>> path=<<path>>/>\n\\end\n\n\\define toc-selective-expandable(tag,sort:\"\",itemClassFilter,exclude,path)\n<$vars tag=<<__tag__>> sort=<<__sort__>> itemClassFilter=<<__itemClassFilter__>> path={{{ [<__path__>addsuffix[/]addsuffix<__tag__>] }}}>\n  <$set name=\"excluded\" filter=\"\"\"[enlist<__exclude__>] [<__tag__>]\"\"\">\n             "text": "\\define leaf-link(full-title,chunk,separator: \"/\")\n<$link to=<<__full-title__>>><$text text=<<__chunk__>>/></$link>\n\\end\n\n\\define leaf-node(prefix,chunk)\n<li>\n<$list filter=\"[<__prefix__>addsuffix<__chunk__>is[shadow]] [<__prefix__>addsuffix<__chunk__>is[tiddler]]\" variable=\"full-title\">\n<$list filter=\"[<full-title>removeprefix<__prefix__>]\" variable=\"chunk\">\n<span>{{$:/core/images/file}}</span> <$macrocall $name=\"leaf-link\" full-title=<<full-title>> chunk=<<chunk>>/>\n</$list>\n</$list>\n</li>\n\\end\n\n\\define branch-node(prefix,chunk,separator: \"/\")\n<li>\n<$set name=\"reveal-state\" value={{{ [[$:/state/tree/]addsuffix<__prefix__>addsuffix<__chunk__>] }}}>\n<$reveal type=\"nomatch\" filter=\"[all[shadows+tiddlers]removeprefix<__prefix__>removeprefix<__chunk__>] -[<__prefix__>addsuffix<__chunk__>]\"/>)</span>\n<$reveal type=\"match\" stateTitle=<<reveal-state>> text=\"show\">\n<$macrocall $name=\"tree-node\" prefix={{{ [<__prefix__>addsuffix<__chunk__>] }}} separator=<<__separator__>>/>\n</$reveal>\n</$set>\n</li>\n\\end\n\n\\define tree-node(prefix,separator: \"/\")\n<ol>\n<$list filter=\"[all[shadows+tiddlers]removeprefix<__prefix__>splitbefore<__separator__>sort[]!suffix<__separator__>]\" variable=\"chunk\">\n<$macrocall filter=\"[all[shadows+tiddlers]removeprefix<__prefix__>splitbefore<__separator__>sort[]suffix<__separator__>]\" variable=\"chunk\">\n<$macrocall $name=\"branch-node\" prefix=<<__prefix__>> chunk=<<chunk>> separator=<<__separator__>>/>\n</$list>\n</ol>\n\\end\n\n\\define tree(prefix: \"$:/\",separator: \"/\")\n<div class=\"tc-tree\">\n<span><$text             "text": "\\define expandable-stylesheets-list()\n<ol>\n<$list filter=\"[all[shadows+tiddlers]tag[$:/tags/Stylesheet]!has[draft.of]]\">\n<$vars state=<<qualify \"$:/state/peek-stylesheets/open/\">>>\n<$set name=\"state\" value={{{ [<state>addsuffix<currentTiddler>] }}}>\n<li>\n<$reveal type=\"match\" state=<<state>> text=\"yes\" tag=\"span\">\n<$button set=<<state>> setTo=\"no\" class=\"tc-btn-invisible\">\n{{$:/core/images/down-arrow}}\n</$button>\n</$reveal>\n<$reveal type=\"nomatch\" state=<<state>> text=\"yes\" tag=\"span\">\n<$button filter=\"[all[shadows+tiddlers]tag[$:/tags/Stylesheet]!has[draft.of]]\">\n<li>\n<$link>\n<$view field=\"title\"/>\n</$link>\n<$set name=\"source\" tiddler=<<currentTiddler>>>\n<$wikify name=\"styles\" \"$:/state/peek-stylesheets/mode/\">>>\n\n<$reveal type=\"nomatch\" state=<<modeState>> text=\"expanded\" tag=\"div\">\n<$button set=<<modeState>> setTo=\"expanded\" {{$:/language/ControlPanel/Stylesheets/Restore/Caption}}</$button>\n</$reveal>\n\n<$reveal type=\"nomatch\" state=<<modeState>> text=\"expanded\"     "tiddlers": {

            "text": "{{$:/core/images/menu-button}}",

            "modifier": "Mat von TWaddle",

!Table of Contents

{{Table of Contents}}

<hr>
Change the content of this by editing $:/plugins/TWaddle/LeftBar/Menu 

<pre>button.leftbar-toggle {
	position:fixed;
	z-index: 1200;
	display:{{!!display}};
	top:0px;
	left:0px;
	padding:0px;
	height:3em;
	width:2em;
}
.leftbar-toggle svg {
	<<transition "fill 150ms ease-in-out">>
	fill: <<colour muted-foreground>>;
}
.leftbar-toggle:hover svg {
	fill: <<colour foreground>>;
}
.leftbar-togglezone {
	position:fixed;
	left:0;
	top:3em;
	min-height:50vh;
	width:1em;
}
.leftbar-settingstable {
	margin:
	0 auto;
}
.leftbar-settingstable,
 .leftbar-settingstable td {
	border:0;
}
.leftbar-settingstable td:nth-of-type(1) {
	text-align:right;
	vertical-align:top;
}
.leftbar-content {
	position:{{!!position}};
	max-width:calc(42px + {{!!width}});
	left:0px;
	top:3em;
	padding:0em 10px 5px 10px;
	background:none;
	min-height:50vh;
	max-height:85vh;
	overflow-y:auto;
}
.leftbar-content .tc-tab-buttons button.tc-tab-selected {
	background-color: <<colour sidebar-tab-background-selected>>;
}
.leftbar-content .tc-tab-buttons button {
	background-color: <<colour sidebar-tab-background>>;
}
.leftbar-togglezone .leftbar-content {
	display:none;
	position:fixed;
}
.leftbar-togglezone:hover .leftbar-content {
	display:{{$:/plugins/TWaddle/LeftBar/Stylesheet!!hover-to-display-as}};
	background:#f4f4f4;
	<<box-shadow "1px 1px 5px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3)">>
 }

@media (max-width: {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/metrics/sidebarbreakpoint}}) {
	.leftbar-content  {
		display:block;
		background:#f4f4f4;
		<<box-shadow "1px 1px 5px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.3)">>
		max-width:90vw;
	}
	button.leftbar-toggle {
		background:transparent;
		height:2em;
	}
	button.leftbar-toggle svg {
		background:white;
	}
	button.leftbar-toggle:hover {
		outline:2px solid lightgray;
	}
}
</pre>

        "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/base": {
            "title": "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/base",
            "tags": "[[$:/tags/Stylesheet]]",
            "text": "\\define custom-background-datauri()\n<$set name=\"background\" value={{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/backgroundimage}}>\n<$list filter=\"[<background>is[image]]\">\n`background: url(`\n<$list filter=\"[<background>!has[_canonical_uri]]\">\n`\"`<$macrocall $name=\"datauri\" tiddler={{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/backgroundimage}} field=\"_canonical_uri\"/>`\"`\n</$list>\n`) center center;`\n`background-attachment: `{{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/backgroundimageattachment}}`;\n-webkit-background-size:` {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/backgroundimagesize}}`;\n-moz-background-size:` {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/backgroundimagesize}}`;\n-o-background-size:` {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/backgroundimagesize}}`;\nbackground-size:` {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/backgroundimagesize}}`;`\n</$list>\n</$set>\n\\end\n\n\\define if-fluid-fixed(text,hiddenSidebarText)\n<$reveal state=\"$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/options/sidebarlayout\" type=\"match\" text=\"fluid-fixed\">\n$text$\n<$reveal state=\"$:/state/sidebar\" type=\"nomatch\" text=\"yes\" default=\"yes\">\n$hiddenSidebarText$\n</$reveal>\n</$reveal>\n\\end\n\n\\define if-editor-height-fixed(then,else)\n<$reveal state=\"$:/config/TextEditor/EditorHeight/Mode\" type=\"match\" text=\"fixed\">\n$then$\n</$reveal>\n<$reveal state=\"$:/config/TextEditor/EditorHeight/Mode\" type=\"match\" text=\"auto\">\n$else$\n</$reveal>\n\\end\n\n\\rules only filteredtranscludeinline transcludeinline macrodef macrocallinline macrocallblock\n\n/*\n** Start with the normalize CSS reset, and then belay some of its effects\n*/\n\n{{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/reset}}\n\n*, input[type=\"search\"] {\n\tbox-sizing: border-box;\n\t-moz-box-sizing: border-box;\n\t-webkit-box-sizing: border-box;\n}\n\nhtml button {\n\tline-height: 1.2;\n\tcolor: <<colour button-foreground>>;\n\tbackground: <<colour button-background>>;\n\tborder-color: <<colour button-border>>;\n}\n\n/*\n** Basic element styles\n*/\n\nhtml {\n\tfont-family: {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/fontfamily}};\n\ttext-rendering: optimizeLegibility; /* Enables kerning and ligatures etc. */\n\t-webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased;\n\t-moz-osx-font-smoothing: grayscale;\n}\n\nhtml:-webkit-full-screen {\n\tbackground-color: <<colour page-background>>;\n}\n\nbody.tc-body {\n\tfont-size: {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/metrics/fontsize}};\n\tline-height: {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/metrics/lineheight}};\n\tword-wrap: break-word;\n\t<<custom-background-datauri>>\n\tcolor: <<colour foreground>>;\n\tbackground-color: <<colour page-background>>;\n\tfill: <<colour foreground>>;\n}\n\n<<if-background-attachment \"\"\"\n\nbody.tc-body {\n        background-color: transparent;\n}\n\n\"\"\">>\n\nh1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 {\n\tline-height: 1.2;\n\tfont-weight: 300;\n}\n\npre {\n\tdisplay: block;\n\tpadding: 14px;\n\tmargin-top: 1em;\n\tmargin-bottom: 1em;\n\tword-break: normal;\n\tword-wrap: break-word;\n\twhite-space: {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/options/codewrapping}};\n\tbackground-color: <<colour pre-background>>;\n\tborder: 1px solid <<colour pre-border>>;\n\tpadding: 0 3px 2px;\n\tborder-radius: 3px;\n\tfont-family: {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/codefontfamily}};\n}\n\ncode {\n\tcolor: <<colour code-foreground>>;\n\tbackground-color: <<colour code-background>>;\n\tborder: 1px solid <<colour code-border>>;\n\twhite-space: {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/options/codewrapping}};\n\tpadding: 0 3px 2px;\n\tborder-radius: 3px;\n\tfont-family: {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/codefontfamily}};\n}\n\nblockquote {\n\tborder-left: 5px solid <<colour blockquote-bar>>;\n\tmargin-left: 25px;\n\tpadding-left: 10px;\n\tquotes: \"\\201C\"\"\\201D\"\"\\2018\"\"\\2019\";\n}\n\nblockquote > div {\n\tmargin-top: 1em;\n\tmargin-bottom: 1em;\n}\n\nblockquote.tc-big-quote {\n\tfont-family: Georgia, serif;\n\tposition: relative;\n\tbackground: <<colour pre-background>>;\n\tborder-left: none;\n\tmargin-left: 50px;\n\tmargin-right: 50px;\n\tpadding: 10px;\n    border-radius: 8px;\n}\n\nblockquote.tc-big-quote cite:before {\n\tcontent: \"\\2014 \\2009\";\n}\n\nblockquote.tc-big-quote:before {\n\tfont-family: Georgia, serif;\n\tcolor: <<colour blockquote-bar>>;\n\tcontent: open-quote;\n\tfont-size: 8em;\n\tline-height: 0.1em;\n\tmargin-right: 0.25em;\n\tvertical-align: -0.4em;\n\tposition: absolute;\n    left: -50px;\n    top: 42px;\n}\n\nblockquote.tc-big-quote:after margin-bottom: 0.5em;\n}\n\n.tc-alert-body > p {\n\tmargin: 0;\n}\n\n.tc-alert-highlight {\n\tcolor: <<colour alert-highlight>>;\n}\n\n@media (min-width:         "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/reset": {
            "title": "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/reset",
            "type": "text/plain",
            "text": "/*! normalize.css v8.0.1 | MIT License | github.com/necolas/normalize.css */\n\n/* Document\n   ========================================================================== */\n\n/**\n * 1. Correct the line height in all browsers.\n * 2. Prevent adjustments of font size after orientation changes in iOS.\n */\n\nhtml {\n  line-height: 1.15; /* 1 */\n  -webkit-text-size-adjust: 100%; /* 2 */\n}\n\n/* Sections\n   ========================================================================== */\n\n/**\n * Remove the margin in all browsers.\n */\n\nbody {\n  margin: 0;\n}\n\n/**\n * Render the `main` element consistently in IE.\n */\n\nmain {\n  display: block;\n}\n\n/**\n * Correct the font size and margin on `h1` elements within `section` and\n * `article` contexts in Chrome, Firefox, and Safari.\n */\n\nh1 {\n  font-size: 2em;\n  margin: 0.67em 0;\n}\n\n/* Grouping content\n   ========================================================================== */\n\n/**\n * 1. Add the correct box sizing in Firefox.\n * 2. Show the overflow in Edge and IE.\n */\n\nhr {\n  box-sizing: content-box; /* 1 */\n  height: 0; /* 1 */\n  overflow: visible; /* 2 */\n}\n\n/**\n * 1. Correct the inheritance and scaling of font size in all browsers.\n * 2. Correct the odd `em` font sizing in all browsers.\n */\n\npre {\n  font-family: monospace, monospace; /* 1 */\n  font-size: 1em; /* 2 */\n}\n\n/* Text-level semantics\n   ========================================================================== */\n\n/**\n * Remove the gray background on active links in IE 10.\n */\n\na {\n  background-color: transparent;\n}\n\n/**\n * 1. Remove the bottom border in Chrome 57-\n * 2. Add the correct text decoration in Chrome, Edge, IE, Opera, and Safari.\n */\n\nabbr[title] {\n  border-bottom: none; /* 1 */\n  text-decoration: underline; /* 2 */\n  text-decoration: underline dotted; /* 2 */\n}\n\n/**\n * Add the correct font weight in Chrome, Edge, and Safari.\n */\n\nb,\nstrong {\n  font-weight: bolder;\n}\n\n/**\n * 1. Correct the inheritance and scaling of font size in all browsers.\n * 2. Correct the odd `em` font sizing in all browsers.\n */\n\ncode,\nkbd,\nsamp {\n  font-family: monospace, monospace; /* 1 */\n  font-size: 1em; /* 2 */\n}\n\n/**\n * Add the correct font size in all browsers.\n */\n\nsmall {\n  font-size: 80%;\n}\n\n/**\n * Prevent `sub` and `sup` elements from affecting the line height in\n * all browsers.\n */\n\nsub,\nsup {\n  font-size: 75%;\n  line-height: 0;\n  position: relative;\n  vertical-align: baseline;\n}\n\nsub {\n  bottom: -0.25em;\n}\n\nsup {\n  top: -0.5em;\n}\n\n/* Embedded content\n   ========================================================================== */\n\n/**\n * Remove the border on images inside links in IE 10.\n */\n\nimg {\n  border-style: none;\n}\n\n/* Forms\n   ========================================================================== */\n\n/**\n * 1. Change the font styles in all browsers.\n * 2. Remove the margin in Firefox and Safari.\n */\n\nbutton,\ninput,\noptgroup,\nselect,\ntextarea {\n  font-family: inherit; /* 1 */\n  font-size: 100%; /* 1 */\n  line-height: 1.15; /* 1 */\n  margin: 0; /* 2 */\n}\n\n/**\n * Show the overflow in IE.\n * 1. Show the overflow in Edge.\n */\n\nbutton,\ninput { /* 1 */\n  overflow: visible;\n}\n\n/**\n * Remove the inheritance of text transform in Edge, Firefox, and IE.\n * 1. Remove the inheritance of text transform in Firefox.\n */\n\nbutton,\nselect { /* 1 */\n  text-transform: none;\n}\n\n/**\n * Correct the inability to style clickable types in iOS and Safari.\n */\n\nbutton,\n[type=\"button\"],\n[type=\"reset\"],\n[type=\"submit\"] {\n  -webkit-appearance: button;\n}\n\n/**\n * Remove the inner border and padding in Firefox.\n */\n\nbutton::-moz-focus-inner,\n[type=\"button\"]::-moz-focus-inner,\n[type=\"reset\"]::-moz-focus-inner,\n[type=\"submit\"]::-moz-focus-inner {\n  border-style: none;\n  padding: 0;\n}\n\n/**\n * Restore the focus styles unset by the previous rule.\n */\n\nbutton:-moz-focusring,\n[type=\"button\"]:-moz-focusring,\n[type=\"reset\"]:-moz-focusring,\n[type=\"submit\"]:-moz-focusring {\n  outline: 1px dotted ButtonText;\n}\n\n/**\n * Correct the padding in Firefox.\n */\n\nfieldset {\n  padding: 0.35em 0.75em 0.625em;\n}\n\n/**\n * 1. Correct the text wrapping in Edge and IE.\n * 2. Correct the color inheritance from `fieldset` elements in IE.\n * 3. Remove the padding so developers are not caught out when they zero out\n *    `fieldset` elements in all browsers.\n */\n\nlegend {\n  box-sizing: border-box; /* 1 */\n  color: inherit; /* 2 */\n  display: table; /* 1 */\n  max-width: 100%; /* 1 */\n  padding: 0; /* 3 */\n  white-space: normal; /* 1 */\n}\n\n/**\n * Add the correct vertical alignment in Chrome, Firefox, and Opera.\n */\n\nprogress {\n  vertical-align: baseline;\n}\n\n/**\n * Remove the default vertical scrollbar in IE 10+.\n */\n\ntextarea {\n  overflow: auto;\n}\n\n/**\n * 1. Add the correct box sizing in IE 10.\n * 2. Remove the padding in IE 10.\n */\n\n[type=\"checkbox\"],\n[type=\"radio\"] {\n  box-sizing: border-box; /* 1 */\n  padding: 0; /* 2 */\n}\n\n/**\n * Correct the cursor style of increment and decrement buttons in Chrome.\n */\n\n[type=\"number\"]::-webkit-inner-spin-button,\n[type=\"number\"]::-webkit-outer-spin-button {\n  height: auto;\n}\n\n/**\n * 1. Correct the odd appearance in Chrome and Safari.\n * 2. Correct the outline style in Safari.\n */\n\n[type=\"search\"] {\n  -webkit-appearance: textfield; /* 1 */\n  outline-offset: -2px; /* 2 */\n}\n\n/**\n * Remove the inner padding in Chrome and Safari on macOS.\n */\n\n[type=\"search\"]::-webkit-search-decoration {\n  -webkit-appearance: none;\n}\n\n/**\n * 1. Correct the inability to style clickable types in iOS and Safari.\n * 2. Change font properties to `inherit` in Safari.\n */\n\n::-webkit-file-upload-button {\n  -webkit-appearance: button; /* 1 */\n  font: inherit; /* 2 */\n}\n\n/* Interactive\n   ========================================================================== */\n\n/*\n * Add the correct display in Edge, IE 10+, and Firefox.\n */\n\ndetails {\n  display: block;\n}\n\n/*\n * Add the correct display in all browsers.\n */\n\nsummary {\n  display: list-item;\n}\n\n/* Misc\n   ========================================================================== */\n\n/**\n * Add the correct display in IE 10+.\n */\n\ntemplate {\n  display: none;\n}\n\n/**\n * Add the correct display in IE 10.\n */\n\n[hidden] {\n  display: none;\n}\n"
        },
        "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/fontfamily": {
            "title": "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/fontfamily",
            "text": "-apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, \"Segoe UI\", Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif, \"Apple Color Emoji\", \"Segoe UI Emoji\", \"Segoe UI Symbol\""
        },
        "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/codefontfamily": {
            "title": "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/codefontfamily",
            "text": "\"SFMono-Regular\",Consolas,\"Liberation Mono\",Menlo,Courier,monospace"
        },
        "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/backgroundimageattachment": {
            "title": "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/backgroundimageattachment",
            "text": "fixed"
        },
        "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/backgroundimagesize": {
            "title": "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/settings/backgroundimagesize",
            "text": "auto"
        },
        "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/sticky": {
            "title": "$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/sticky",
            "text": "<$reveal state=\"$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/options/stickytitles\" type=\"match\" text=\"yes\">\n``\n.tc-tiddler-title {\n\tposition: -webkit-sticky;\n\tposition: -moz-sticky;\n\tposition: -o-sticky;\n\tposition: -ms-sticky;\n\tposition: sticky;\n\ttop: 0px;\n\tbackground: ``<<colour tiddler-background>>``;\n\tz-index: 500;\n}\n\n``\n<$list filter=\"[range[100]]\">\n`.tc-story-river .tc-tiddler-frame:nth-child(100n+`<$text text=<<currentTiddler>>/>`) {\nz-index: `<$text text={{{ [[200]subtract<currentTiddler>] }}}/>`;\n}\n`\n</$list>\n</$reveal>\n"
        }
    }
}






/*LeftBar*/ calc({{$:/plugins/TWaddle/LeftBar/Stylesheet!!width}} + {{$:/plugins/TWaddle/LeftBar/temp!!storyleft}})






/*LeftBar*/ calc({{$:/plugins/TWaddle/LeftBar/temp!!storyright}} + {{$:/themes/tiddlywiki/vanilla/metrics/storyleft}})






684px






fluid-fixed






yes












chromodrome-game






classic






The following rules are an addendum to special circumstances that may arise during normal play. They clarify the intention of the rules, particularly about combat, and curb probable rules abuse.

!Combat

!!Aiming
When rolling to perform a ranged attack against targets, you suffer one burn on the roll. To aim at a target, it takes a quick action and you are assumed to be aiming at the target until the target has complete cover, or you lose the ability to aim

!!Dodging
You cannot dodge an attack or something that you are not aware of. You suffer one burn on dodging ranged attacks, and can use your Brawl to dodge attacks in melee.

!!Multi-Weapon Attacks
When rolling to attack someone while you hold separate but similar weapons  in both your hands, you may attack using both weapons in the same action but suffer one burn for light weapons, and two burn for heavy weapons. You roll for each weapon separately.

!!Multi-Target Attacks
When you roll to attack multiple targets you roll once for all targets and divide the number of success among the targets, starting with the closest target. Any additional hits beyond the minimum required for success are used against the other targets. If targets are equally distant from you, divide the number of successes equally. Targeting in this manner can be described in terms as general as "down the corridor," "through the windshield," and "around the table"

!Armor Stacking
Should a character have multiple sources of armor protecting against the same sort of damage, the armor only partially stacks. Take the highest source of armor against that damage and add to it half the second highest armor against that damage. That is your effective armor against that type of damage.

!Barrier Stacking
Barriers from the same/similar source do not stack, but barrier can be layered from different sources. Otherwise follow a similar calculation as done for armor stacking

!Group Contacts
Sometimes you will gain a contact that is best described not as a single person, but instead an organization. This could be due to knowing many people in a single organization. You can still represent the whole organization as a contact giving you multiple points of contact. A common example might be a shadowBiz, or a family. Others might be old contact that are all similar enough that as you level up are better treated as a group instead of 3 or 5 separate identities. And finally, a group contact could also be a sub style you are a part of. 

Whatever it is, the group contact has 1 additional area of expertise. This extra benefit comes with an additional cost of 1 SC per loyalty and connection.

!Deciding Abilities
Also previously described, the GM decides what ability to use when a roll is called for or required. The ability to use though is dependent on the action of object used.  The following is a short list of decisions:

* For melee attacks made with light weapons use [[Coordination]], otherwise use [[Athletics]].
*For ranged attacks used with weapons that you cannot aim without the aid of another character or gear due to weight, cumbersomeness, or recoil roll with [[Athletics]]. Otherwise use [[Coordination]].










The value of an ability is the quantified appraisal of a character on a 1-10 point scale.  There are ten ''Abilities'' used during play: [[Athletics]], [[Charm]], [[Coercive]], [[Cool]], [[Coordination]], [[Empathy]], [[Hearty]], [[Luck]], [[Perception]] and [[Smarts]].  Each one serves as a measure of a character’s ability to act independent of the subject or object they are acting upon or acting against. The Abilities serve as character descriptions, measures of how well they fit a role, or measures of raw talent, strength and weakness. 

Abilities are used to determine the number used to determine your character’s chances of success and failure.  For each die in the dice pool, if the value of the top showing face is less than or equal to the ability score used to roll, the dice counts as a ''Hit''. See [[Determining Success]] for more information.

!! Modified Abilities
Some gear will provide a ''Modified Ability Score'' due to the use of gear such as cybernetics, implants, and drugs. These modified scores are record separately but next to the base Ability Scores. There are some environments and spaces that such items cannot modify your character abilities.  Examples include a cybernetic liver to resist the effects of a narcotic, algorithms in [[Cyberspace]], or [[Cyberware]] that has been disabled by a [[Cowboy|Cowboys]].  In these cases, use your characters base abilities instead.

!! Abilities 10 and above
A character cannot naturally modify their abilities scores to or above 10. Cyberware and other gear allow people to surpass this natural limitation of the human form, allowing characters to have modified scores 10 and higher. Should a character be required to roll using an ability of a score 10 or higher, the character rolls as if their ability score is 9 but gains one automatic success at ability scores equal to 10 and additional successes for every 3 points above 10.








Actions come in four types. The first being a Complex Action, which requires the character’s complete turn and total focus to accomplish. The second is a Quick Action, which requires some but not all focus and which occurs quickly but not suddenly. Thirdly there are Reflexive Actions which takes little to no focus, and can be accomplished near instantaneously.  There is a final type of action call a free action, that require very little time or effort and typically is done while taking another action. Examples are included below:

|!Type | !Examples |
|Complex |Interfacing with [[The Net]] or [[Drone Rig]], sprinting down a hall, searching a container, steering a car, going defensive. |
|Quick |Aim at a target, use a simple object, throw a thing, slot a program, move a small object, open a latch door, instruct an [[NPC]] |
|Reflexive |Shoot a gun, press a button, hold your breath, take cover, speak shortly |
|Free |Shout for help, drop an item, release a grappled target, shifting in place, peek around something |

On your turn you may take the following assortment of actions:

*One Complex, One Reactive
*Two Quicks
*One Quick , Two Reactives








''Aeschbacher-Mitsui Orbital Bank,'' or A-MOB, is the largest financial institution in the world, which is strange since it's headquartered on a private space station at Earth's Lagrange Point 5. Not much is known able to private institution except that it is operated and presumably owned by the multinational Aeserbach-Mitsui conglomerate, and that they control the reserve currency of the world, [[The Nova Kredit|Nova Kredits]].

!!Power
A-MOB is the financial lending monopoly, and are the primary lender and holder of most corporate and many government debts. It is presumed that once they realizing the precarious nature of having the bank in borders of countries they lend so much to, they acquired and modernized the Tsiolkovsky Space Habitat from the then flagging USSR.






Those that can do more than just survive the streets grow, prosper and gain power in the forms of wealth and information.  This power is fleeting not just because rain gutters are filled with punks, but because once a punk has too much power for too long they become a part of the establishment: the Man, the sell-out, one of them.  

In a world of violence, oppression, and where morality is a style choice, it is acceptable to take power by force or through illicit means. Some grandpa’s mother would call that a travesty. We call that living the edge.  Any day you might slice yourself on the edge, or someone throws you back into the light or back into the shadows of the street.  It’s always up to you to decide what social order you’ll enforce when you’re on the top of the pile, but when those days of feast come, we feast.  We already survived the famine.  







Whenever you divide a number during play, always round down and ignore the remainder or numbers after the decimal.






<<<
Congratulations on being employed by Mexon Industries and welcome to Zen City, your new home. A good place where you are safe to work, live, and laugh as you continue your employment in America's best company.

- Mexon Industries/Zen City onboarding materials
<<<

''Arcologies'' are mega-structures larger than multiple [[Blocks]] combined and serve as a self contained systems that houses industry, commercial interests and residents. Arcologies were originally designed prior to the turn of the millennia as a theoretical solution to urban sprawl, ecological impact, and transportation. By keeping everything within the arcology, the costs in time, fuel, and real estate could be solve by expanding upwards into 3 dimensions. The first arcology built in [[The Texaplex]] was By [[Texas Instruments]] and houses/employees 59,000 employees.

Today all arcologies are built and owned by [[Megacorporations]]. They function as cities closed off from the rest of the world and produce their own food, industry and people. Employees work, live and sleep their entire lives within an arcology's walls, spending the money they earned to buy and lease all that they have in stores and on goods manufactured and owned by the same corporations and the subsidiaries that pay them.

Due to the complexity involved in managing such a resource dense enclosure, it is far from rare for Arcologies to be overseen by a specialized [[Artificial Intelligence]] that manages virtually every aspect of the arcology. Only the largest and powerful entities are capable of having the pre-existing resources to build and continue to manage the arcology, such as [[The Big 12]].

!!Arcology Geography
The general layout and design of each Arcology is different, adding a signature feature to the skyline of the cities they reside in. However, each arcology is a series of levels where the higher the level the smaller the available floor space. This gives all arcologies a tapered or pyramid profile. Other shapes to exist, but even then they are typically spheroids like the Three Metals Center in Detroit, or cylindrical like the Lengdaong superstructure in New Agora.

The interior of arcologies place people close to virtual all other aspects of their life. Work, food, and recreation are all within walking space of every employee’s residence. Should  transportation be required, a diversity of fuel-efficient options are available. Independent automobiles are typically only allowed for official corporate business purposes and not allowed for personal use by employees.

!!Additional Info
Residence in an arcology is dependent upon employment. Too many wage-slaves or sararīman end up on the street after being fired with no connect to the people they’ve known for decades or their entire life. They don’t usually last long in the shadows.

Given the layers of security and control a corporation has over their arcology, it takes a specialized team of jobber to break into or infiltrate. A common sort of run is to extract high valued targets from one megacorporation and deliver them to a second megacorporation. However, if the extraction is from an arcology, the job just becomes a magnitude harder. Solos, the best of the best are the ones who make it in and out of an arcology extraction job.








!!__''Heavy Coat''__
!!!!Armor I (restricted i), Armor I (restricted i) – 10 SC
A thick coat, typically made of wool or a thick material which provides minimal protection and can be cumbersome. Reduce the damage received from ''cutting '' or ''crushing '' attacks by 2 per success.  Whenever you attempt to do something gymnastic you suffer one burn.


!!__''Leather Jacket''__
!!!!Armor II – 10 SC
Originally a waste length jacket formed out of the hide of various animals, today’s leather jacket is composed artificial materials like plastics and synthetic fibers.  This has not reduced the protective abilities of the jackets, particularly authentic replicas. While wearing a leather jacket, you reduce all cutting damage by 3 per success.


!!__''Light undershirt''__
!!!!Harm I, Concealment I – 12 SC
A protective shirt worn under other articles of clothing that offer minimal protection but effective in reducing harm from bullets. When wearing a light shirt, you reduce ballistics damage by 2 per every success of the attack. When a person rolls to detect or locate the shirt using sight or touch, they suffer 1 burn.


!!__''Kevlar-lined coat''__
!!!!Armor II, Armor I – 15 SC
A coat lined with Kevlar to help stop the impact of bullets other heavy impacts. When wearing the Kevlar-lined coat, you reduce the damage suffered from ''ballistic ''damage by 3 per success on the attack and reduces the ''crushing'' damage suffered by 2 per success on the attack.


!!__''Concealed Vest''__
!!!!Armor II, Armor I – 15 SC
A small vest capable of being worn underneath  a persons usual clothing, a concealed vest is often used to minimize the effectiveness of blades weapons and some weapons through the use of specialized fibers. When wearing the concealed vest, you reduce ''ballistic ''damage by 3 per success on the attack and reduces the ''cutting ''damage suffered by 2 per success on the attack.


!!__''Stab Vest''__
!!!!Armor III, Armor I – 20 SC
Often flat fronted and backed, a stab vest is commonly issued to urban or metro police officers. It’s sleek yet dark design is intended to be professional and menacing. As it’s name denotes, the stab vest is more effective at resisting piercing damage and offers minimal protection against bullets. When wearing the stab vest, you reduce ''blade ''damage by 4 per success on the attack and reduces the ''ballistic ''damage suffered by 2 per success on the attack.


!!__''Tactical Vest''__
!!!!Armor II, Armor I, Armor I – 20 SC
Composed of a multitude of materials, a tactical vest provides overall protection for life on the rough streets. A general protective clothing, a tactical vest is produced and sold by a variety of corporations as well as can be produced on the streets. When wearing a tactical vest, you reduce ''ballistic'' damage by 3, ''cutting'' damage by 2, and ''crushing'' damage suffered by 2 per success on the attack.


!!__''Special Tactics''__
!!!!Armor III, Armor III, Armor I – 25 SC
A class of armor typically donned by armed service members, special tactics armor is the light weight yet protective alternative between light and heavier armor. It offers an option intended for use with other gear and additional situation armors. Today, many corpSec guards and some higher funded gangers use the armor for their daily missions and activities. When wearing the special tactics armor, you reduce the damage suffered from bullet damage by 4, reduce the damage suffered from blade damage by 4, and reduces the crushing damage suffered by 2 per success on the attack. Additionally, whenever you are wearing the armor and attempt quite or soft movement, you suffer one burn. While wearing special tactics armor, you suffer 1 burn of feats of acrobatics.


!!__''Combat Armor''__
!!!!Armor IV, Armor III, Armor II – 25 SC
Combat armor is some of the best of conventional armor available. The armor provides a full body coverage , protecting the entire body in layers of in highly durable armor while sacrificing only some mobility. When wearing combat armor, you reduce the damage suffered from ''ballistic ''damage by 5, reduce the damage suffered from ''cutting'' damage by 4, and reduces the ''crushing ''damage suffered by 3 per success on the attack. Additionally, whenever you are wearing the armor and attempt quite or soft movement, you suffer one burn.







''Athletics'' is a measure of a character’s physical fitness and conditioning.  Example activities include running, jumping, climbing, holding or carrying heavy objects, and breaking down obstacles. Character able to lift heavy objects, sprint long distances, wield heavier weapons to deal more damage have high Athletics scores 






Serving as the south-western point of the Texaplex, Austin-San Antonio is fastest growing metroplex in the Texaplex. San Antonio and Austin are connected by I-35 and a web of state highways and back rounds giving it a boomerang shape.

!!San Antonio
The largest of the two cities by land and population, ''San Antonio'', or San An, anchors the southwestern point of the Texaplex. San Antonio was originally a Spanish monastery and boasts a rich colonial heritage today. It is the current home of [[The Alamo]], an important landmark of Texan independence and pride.

San Antonio also has a strong military presence as multiple former US armed service stations and bases are populated and controlled by Texas Rangers, the Texas National Guard, and various private military corporations. Due to its being within 100 miles of the Southern Boarder of the State of Texas, San Antonio serves as an immigration pathway into Texaplex from The United States of Mexico.

These immigrants often settle within the western and southern portions of San Antonio, blending their culture with the already present Texan and Tejano cultures. This has produced a unique microcosm of both nationalist and class violence and Latinx identities due to the Mexican-American War to claim the entire Rio Grande River Valley. Groups that have grown up in such areas of San Antonio street cultures often speak a fusion of English and Spanish referred to as Texican, a pidgen language unique to the Texaplex.

The Historical Riverwalk is a common tourist attraction in the city situated in and around downtown. Downtown San An has both a vibrant day and nightlife, and is mostly owned by corporations. However a few local favorites such as Casa Rio continue to serve the city to this day and have porches overlooking the river. A new addition to the river walk is to be complete by 2043, and will be home to 42 new store fronts and restaurants.

!!Austin
The capital of the State of Texas, ''Austin'' is currently home to many small Technology and Net companies, the University of Texas, as well as Weird-Country music star Violet Banshee. Austin is home to many annual music and technology festivals, and it's numerous convention spaces are used for corporate expos and similar events.

As the State Capital, it also serves as the political capital of the Texaplex. Many embassies and a mosaic of corporate zones dot the entire cities geography, and the Texas Rangers hold headquarters within the cities limits.

Austin’s hills oppose little complaint from the cities bicycle and ride-sharing means of transportation. Austin is also home to the Austin Looping Rails System. In fact, everything is mobile in Austin, who’s infrastructure supports a large volume of transient business that travel via rail and street. Commuter travelling companies such as [[Otto's]] and [[ZiggyRide]] provide electric and mass commute options for those who do not have means autonomous travel.







* ''Avatar'' – a digital construct in virtual reality or the Net analogous to a body or form in the real world
* ''Bang on!'' – an affirmative injection expressing emphatic agreement with a previous statement.
* ''Biochip'' – a computer chip or drive which connects directly to biological living matter.
* ''Bio-ware'' – Genetically engineered or designed body parts that replace, enhance, or augment previously existing bodily functions.
* ''~BlkStims'' – SimStims that are unsafe due to tampered or missing safety controls. Addictive and dangerous to the user’s psyche. Short for black market simstims.
* ''Block'' – a tall urban structure large enough to be subject to internal zoning laws for residence, industrial and recreation, and may be or been designed to be self-sufficient.
* ''Chip'' – a small thumb nail sized drive that provides digital information, skills, and memory that can be used via a jack.
* ''Chipped'' – a description of a person extensively uses chips for skills and knowledge.
* ''Chip-tune'' – hardware capable of creating or a recording of computer generated music and vocals.
* ''Chizz'' – something that is calm and relaxed, or calming and relaxing to others.
* ''Chrome Domer'' – a person who has most – if not all – of their central nervous system replaced by cybernetics
* ''Cleaner/Cleaning crew'' – persons, typically assassins that work to eliminate loose ends from a job or operation.
* ''Cut-ins'' – dangerous and illegal SimStims that make sensations and experiences heightened and are highly addictive.
* ''Cyberware'' – Hardware or Machine implanted onto a living body and acting as a natural body part through integration with or adoption of the living bodily metabolism or nervous system.
* ''Dome heads'' – slang term for a justiciar, a one-man walking army and justice system.
* ''Drek'' – informal usage for trash or rubbish. Or something that has the qualities of trash or rubbish.
* ''Edgerunner or Runner'' – a person who main means of revenue or wealth is completing dangerous and often time illegal tasks. A deniable asset hired for corporate espionage.
* ''Ergo'' – short for ergophobia:, a person afraid to work. A person accused of failure to work and laziness.
* ''Flats'' – people who have not had or have had only minimal cyberware installed or implanted
* ''Frak //(expletive)//'' – an obscene word used in phrases to denote disdain or to emphasize a heightened emotional context in what is being said.
* ''Frag //(expletive)//'' – a term of violent frustration, or to kill.
* ''Geek'' – to kill.
* ''Heatwave'' – an increase of police or security activity in an area.
* ''Hoser'' – a loser.
* ''Jack-in'' – to connect to cyberspace or a computer system, typically via neural plugs called jacks - A computer or electronic port.
* ''Jump'' - to interface (typically a person) with a drone, cyberspace, virtual reality or computer operated system with sensory integration.
* ''Kemo-sabe'', ''Kemosabe'', ''Kimosabe'' – a term of endearment for a friend.
* ''Kipple'' – useless objects, typically thrown away, that seemingly amass sinisterly without human intervention
* ''Krak'' – informal term to refer to the removal of copy protections of a digital product or good. Also, to gain unauthorized access to or illegitimate authority over a system or group.
* ''Lamp'' – a signal to communicate a dangerous place, I.e “hanging a lamp.”
* ''Marion'' – from marionette, a person capable of being controlled, typically for adult services, by means of cybernetics. see also Bunraku.
* ''Meatspace'' – derogatory or pejorative term for the real world
* ''Mesh'' – a decentralized radio-based alternative to the Net.
* ''Mr. Johnson'' – any anonymous employer or corporate agent.
* ''NEET'' – short for “Not in Education, Employment, or Training.” A person, though not necessarily young who is neither employed, taking education or training courses.
* ''NETainment'' – a form of social media entertainment that arose with the expansion of SimStims technology into the consumer markets and the creation of independent ~SimStim vlogs.
* ''Nova-Kredit'' – the de facto currency of the world and is operated by the Orbital Hang-Weizen Bancorp.
* ''[[NukItz!]]'' – a fast-food burger patty restaurant franchise known for their signature 12 second cooked burger and fries. However, Shift managers are rumored to function as arms and drug dealers in order to earn a living wage.
* ''Bunraku'' – an individual that has had their own personality and/or consciousness neurologically inhibited and replaced by cybernetic means. Also known as Bunny, Maria. See also Marion
* ''Obi'' – an obese slob, or a person who habitually eats super processed insta-meals.
* ''Old Mama'' – an inexperienced or in professional employer or job agent. See and compare to Mr. Johnson.
* ''Oppai'' - Japanese for boobs. something cool.
* ''Pack'' – to eat something quickly. To carry a firearm.
* ''Ping'' – the action of getting another’s attention, typically via an instant message. See also poke.
* ''Pep-joy'' – a heavily caffeinated soft drink known for its impressive mood-altering effects.
* ''Psyche-deck'' – a computer and memory drive that contains a close approximate copy of a person’s memory, personality, and neural mapping in a digital analog.
* ''Real Space'' – the natural sensory world
* ''Sararīman'' – Japanese for salaryman, a salaried white-collar worker who shows loyalty to their employer.
* ''Scan'' – to look, see, read, or observe details, objects, or an environment.
* ''Skiddies'' – a cowboy term for hackers that use programs without understanding how or why a program works or what it is intended to target most effectively. They simply use the program as is. 
* ''SimStims'' – a media type that simulates an experience or sensation via the direct stimulation of a user’s brain.
* ''Slot'' – to insert software, chips or neural ware into a computer drive or socket.
* ''Smeg head'' – a complete and total idiot loser, often a self righteous character.
* ''Sniffer'' – a person or program that searches for an intrusive, unauthorized, or specific user in a computer system or communication line
* ''Stunt'' – to show off, typically in a stylish or exhilarating manner
* ''Tejano'' – citizens and residents of Texas that are descended from Mexican parents that lived in the Texaplex for generations. Some Tejano families belonged in Texas prior to the Texas Revolution.
* ''Texican ''– either an emergent Latinx culture developed in southern Texaplex or the recognized unofficial language of the Texaplex.
* ''Wage-slave'' - a person who’s wholly dependent on their employment to live and survive, often working long or irregular hours.
* ''Wet work'' – jobs involving murder and violence, typically bloody in nature.
* ''Whizz'' – an aerosol based drug or pharmaceutical, or to take by means of aerosol inhalation.
* ''Yak'' – the Yakuza, a Japanese criminal organization.
* ''Zaibatsu'' – one of the largest Japanese corporations that can trace their continued history to medieval Japan. Often privately owned and operated by a single family.







Surrounding the San Pablo, San Francisco and Suisun Bays in Northern California, ''Bay City'' is a city-state known for it's beaches, warm climate, and deep harbors. It is home to many new net corporations, and net media since the [[Net Crash]] and hosts the largest number of [[SimStims]] production companies.






Players who enjoy Chromodrome will hopefully want to tell their stories and find new people who might want to play a game.  The struggles of keeping these stories light and entertaining are the common fascination with numbers - generating the largest ones or talking about all of them when they are small details used in forming the narrative now being told - and explaining the procedures and histories which are their own stories. 

Unfortunately, these details only halt the advance of explaining the story to your audience during and after play.  The mechanics, numbers, rules, and dice are fun, but while a bit of numbers should give a game a good crunch, they do not keep the narrative going so that we experience the sudden double cross while on the job, or the weight of a single dice role in deciding between life or death.

The actions should be described, called, resolved, and in effect in a simple process that only slows down to build the tension and importance of the action being taken.  During play and telling the story afterwards, the stress and tension of the narrative should build and – boom – be released, spilling us into an assortment of new sources of tension and wild narrative decisions.







Playing a table top roleplaying game or "TTRPG" is a lot of fun, but a ''Game Master'' or ''GM'' is the most important facilitator of that fun.  The special role of a GM has many important functions. They provide, decide, or create the primary plot or narrative arc for the rest of the [[players|The Other Players]], referee the actions of all players to verify that play is consistent with the rules, play and act in the place of all the characters that are not the other players’, narrate the characters’ environment or location, provide challenges for the main characters, and control the speed and pacing of the narrative.

While the GM controls antagonists and villains during the game, they are not an enemy or opponent.  TTRPGs are co-operative games where everyone works together to have the most fun. While there is no way to "win" a TTRPG, unlike other table top games like card games or board games, everyone having fun at the table is the closest you can get. And there is a plethora of various TTRPGs available today that are made to have fun in unique, enjoyable and creative ways.







Fighting as sport has always been popular. Wrestling and boxing have always been a popular, but after the introduction of eastern martial arts to American cinema audiences through high action Kung-fu films, a new breed of fighting sports evolved by consumer demand. These Xtreme Martial Wrestling federations began promoting fights. Today, there are many SimStims available from all the greatest fights in the past few decades, and a few recreated from the Golden Wresting Federation flat video archives.

For those looking to experience “the real thing” SimStims can only do so much. Today many low production and often illegal matches are made, bring real blood, sweat and violence into the ring. These blackyarders are the most popular fighting sport of high-flying concussions and acrobatic kicks. The fighters are the adrenaline junkie in your neighborhood looking for real colors and gigs. Often not professionally trained, these fighters come in two major classes: the enhanced and non-enhanced circuits. 

Locating a blackyarding event is not too difficult. Often a booker, trainer, or even the superstar themselves will promote the fight in broad day light on social media. Many fights are booked same day, attracting raw talent to compete from those just looking to watch. Some fights seem not so voluntary, but blackyarding requires fresh talent or either there are enough freaks looking to fight a match.







<<<
They're huge and square and rectangular. They're take up city blocks. They block the sun. I'm guessing here. I don't know why they're called blocks. Just choose any of those and stop asking stupid questions.

-Mr. Happy
<<<


Most blocks are small structures of no less than 20 stories tall and tucked in between the larger more industrial blocks. Due to the rescinding of sunlight laws and ordinances, the typical block structure is a bold rectilinear facade, which could theoretically extend up to a mile tall or 330-420 stories tall. Most larger blocks contain a large central courtyard open to allow air traffic, sunlight access, as well as a cost efficient means of heat regulation and building servicing.

Blocks were originally based on the self sufficient models of eco-futurists of the past century. These buildings, after the toll of overpopulation and scarcity, no longer as fully self sufficient, but are still the homes of both businesses, industrial manufacturing, and private residence. 

Not every block will contain multiple urban and economic function, but blocks in general contain businesses, social clubs, recreational areas, some minor agriculture, power-generation, industrial, and private residences. Blocks tall enough or in the heart of suburban or urban centers that are tall enough, can possibly contain every function or service a modern city.
