Zm6Zgm75fdNzLVZ6n26QAAAAQkECAAAIBQkAACAUJAAAgFCQAAAAQkECAAAIM9/wm5aJ7Ok57snMN2dYaUp4pdxHtfw+uW5nvxc3SAAAAKEgAQAAhIIEAAAQChIAAEAoSAAAAKEgAQAAhJlvbqdl6lqOuzHzzdVMM+9reS9y9/QZ78UNEgAAQChIAAAAoSABAACEggQAABAKEgAAQChIAAAAYeYbftMydT09xz2Z+eYMppn3tbwXuXs6+724QQIAAAgFCQAAIBQkAACAUJAAAABCQQIAAAgFCQAAIMx8w3/UMpE9PcdcZr45imnmfS3vZXqOfSudgxskAACAUJAAAABCQQIAAAgFCQAAIBQkAACAUJAAAADCzDccoGUiuyXHPZn55hEmnfe1vJfpOY519jm4QQIAAAgFCQAAIBQkAACAUJAAAABCQQIAAAgFCQAAIMx8wydrmdZuyTGXmW/eMs28r2XqenqOY610Dm6QAAAAQkECAAAIBQkAACAUJAAAgFCQAAAAQkECAACIl6sfACZomciengNmmTDN3DJZLXdsjn0t5+AGCQAAIBQkAACAUJAAAABCQQIAAAgFCQAAIBQkAACAeN62bbv6IWCylons6TnW9/Pr69WPwGJaJpZbpqfljs2xb8I5uEECAAAIBQkAACAUJAAAgFCQAAAAQkECAAAIBQkAACDMfMOFWiayp+dYg5nvbitN9H6GlulpOc4w/dzdIAEAAISCBAAAEAoSAABAKEgAAAChIAEAAISCBAAAEGa+YVEtE9ktOdZn5vs8LVO7H9UyQSx3bG66s9/Lnc/dDRIAAEAoSAAAAKEgAQAAhIIEAAAQChIAAEAoSAAAAGHmGwq1TGu35FiDme9jTZja/ZOWCWK5Y3PTtbyX6efuBgkAACAUJAAAgFCQAAAAQkECAAAIBQkAACAUJAAAgDDzDcO0TGtPz/E4M9+Pa5nM/aiW6Wm5NXItWn7fnc/dDRIAAEAoSAAAAKEgAQAAhIIEAAAQChIAAEAoSAAAAPFy9QMAj2uZupaD/2+l6dvP0DIlLLdGrkXL73Pu+9wgAQAAhIIEAAAQChIAAEAoSAAAAKEgAQAAhIIEAAAQz9u2bVc/BHCclqlrOd76+fX16kfgL1omgeXWyE3X8j59L49zgwQAABAKEgAAQChIAAAAoSABAACEggQAABAKEgAAQJj5hhtpmbqWuycz32tomQSWWyM3Xcv79L0cyw0SAABAKEgAAAChIAEAAISCBAAAEAoSAABAKEgAAABh5ht4enrqmbqWOza3EjPfj2uZ9pVbI8e+lnPwnZ3HDRIAAEAoSAAAAKEgAQAAhIIEAAAQChIAAEAoSAAAAGHmG/irlslquWNzZzPzva9l2ldujRz7pp/D9N93NjdIAAAAoSABAACEggQAABAKEgAAQChIAAAAoSABAADEy9UPAKxvpelpubm5lbRMOsvdM8e+lnNo+c7u/H26QQIAAAgFCQAAIBQkAACAUJAAAABCQQIAAAgFCQAAIJ63bduufghgppUmpOXWz33/8u3dv600YSsnd0aOfdPPwfe5BjdIAAAAoSABAACEggQAABAKEgAAQChIAAAAoSABAACEmW/gEi3T03Ln5X69/nj3by3Tt3L3zHGs6efnu16fGyQAAIBQkAAAAEJBAgAACAUJAAAgFCQAAIBQkAAAAMLMN7Cclaan5c7Lff/y7d2/rTR9K3fPHMeafn6+625ukAAAAEJBAgAACAUJAAAgFCQAAIBQkAAAAEJBAgAACDPfQJWWyWq5x3O/Xn+8+7eWyVy5NXLTtbyX6efu/2EuN0gAAAChIAEAAISCBAAAEAoSAABAKEgAAAChIAEAAMQ/OD+h0YL2Tq4AAAAASUVORK5CYII=






<<<
"When you jack-in directly to the Net you can sometimes smell data. "

"The only things I ever smell are shit and burning brain jacks"

"Well, but, that's what it smells like in meat space, not in cyberspace"
<<<


```
//Console Jockey, Netrunner, hotdogger, Otaku, Technomancer, Cybersec, Wirehead, Deked, Decker, Breaker//
```

Characters belonging to this archtype are the nexyt evolution in phreakers and hackers. They don't necessarily know computers like a technician does, but they have a natural or innate way of exploring Cybberspace and exploiting the technology behind [[The Net]]. They can unlock systems, override security and gain access to data vaults not intended for their snooping eyes.

!!![[Abilities]] and [[Foci]]

Choose one Ability array from below:

| 3 | !Athletics | 3 |
| 3 | !Charm | 4 |
| 3 | !Coersive | 3 |
| 5 | !Cool | 5 |
| 4 | !Coordination | 4 |
| 2 | !Empathy | 2 |
| 4 | !Hearty | 3 |
| 4 | !Luck | 4 |
| 4 | !Smarts | 5 |
| 5 | ! Perception | 4 |

Choose one array from below for the ranking of your character's foci:

| Interface | !Expert | Computers |
| Netrunning |~| Netrunning |
| Case | !Moderate | Interface |
| Computers |~| Killswitch |
| Security |~| Security |
| Sleuth |~| Sleuth |
| Wipe |~| Wipe |
| Finagle | !Basic | Case |
| Killswitch |~| Deceive |
| Light Weapons |~| Light Weapons |

!!! Typical Equipment
* Cyberdeck
* Console or terminal
* Protocols
* Neural Jacks
* Mnemonic cyberware
* Light pistol
* Light club
* Neural Enhancing drugs
* Digital security

!!! [[Exploits]]
!!!!Two Keyboards
Spend 5 SP to target multiple targets in Cyberspace or The Net with a protocol that has the single-target limitation.

!!!!Like Lightning
You ignore 1 [[Burn]] when you gain access to a node/system in Cyberspace.

!!!!Signature Protocol
Choose a program/protocol. The first time that you use protocol in a scene, you roll with [[Edge]]

!!!!Specialized System
Choose a type of target node/system. The first time that you target an instance of that system/node, you roll with Edge.

!!!!NEET-0
You have edge on rolls whenever you either Interface with a rig or when you Interface into Cyberspace.






[[Block Generation|F: Block Generation]]: Step 5

Bizs, both [[Megacorporations]] and ShadowBizs are the life blood of the economy, and there is no escaping their influences. Each player names and designs a biz in general terms. A name, a focus of industry, and a goal is all that’s needed to create a biz, but even just a name might suffice. The name is self explanatory, but remember to that the name is the easiest way to convey a tone. Is it a crapsacharine name that conveys sweetness but is in fact a shitty company? Give it a girly but kitschy name, like ~PinkHoney. You don’t need to know why that’s the name. Maybe they’re running out of names to register under incorporation laws and that’s all that was left. If they’re a shadowBiz, break all the rules or name it after where they are from, the people that make up the shadowBiz, or follow the [description][noun] pattern.

A focus of industry is what the biz peddles chiefly in and to who. Corps could be broader, but shadowBizs typically deal in slightly more confined markets. A goal is what the shadowBiz is currently focusing on whether it be acquiring real estate, breaking into a new market, developing a good, moving a product, dooming the competition. After you have written these down, all the players pass the notes to the GM, and they will compile them and use them during the storyline.

These bizs should be present during the game, but are not always active. They can be negative but also negative elements. A player can chose to have a [[Contact|Spending Street Cred]] in a bizs, but a bizs can also be the source of a rival. or adversaty [[NPC|Non-Player Characters]].






The rules and GM will prompt you to roll your dice.  In those cases, the rules and GM will say something like “Roll [[Charm]],” “Roll [[Empathy]],” or “Roll X [[Ability|Abilities]].” Where X Ability is the key ability.  This prompts you to create a ''dice pool''. First, choose the most appropriate [[Foci]] for your character as approved by the GM, this will determine the number of dice you collect. Secondly, add or remove dice based on [[Edge]] and [[Burn]]. Then finally roll the dice pool to [[determine success|Determining Success]] based on the key ability.






You now need to customize your character to help make them stand out and be unique.  You do so by spending [[Street Cred]] an in game and meta currency used to purchase gear, increase your character's abilities, and to pull favors from other characters. The GM decides how much Street Cred (or SC) a character starts with, but a character just starting the game should have somewhere between 90-115 street cred for typical play. SC can be spent during character creation and after play.

Characters begin with the following incidental gear:

* One Samsung Xscape [[NetComm]] with a general Net Access contract.
* A B class [[SaIN ID|SaIN IDs]], which grants access to private and public transportation networks.
* A Registered [[KlikStik|KlikStiks]], which grants basic banking.


During Character creation, this will be your longest step. However, options are available in the [[Gear Catalog]] expedite this step. Feel free to pick from one of the many pre-assembled lists for you chosen [[Character Archetype|Character Archetypes]].








!Scorchers

Scorched are programs used to induce harm on digital constructs. They destabilize systems by injecting large amounts of malignant or hard to process data leading to a momentary lapse in performance. For persons targeted by a scorch program, their nerves and brain light up, causing painful neural damage often described as frostbite. Below are common examples and ranking of scorchers, where each can only be used by a terminal, cyberdeck or similar gear item under the control of a user.

!!__D Class__ 
!!!!Harm II (dependent I, single target i) – SC 4 / Block  1

When you execute this program using a deck or similar gear, which is required, you target a single digital target of your choice in immediate range, I.e within the same node as you. For every success when, you deal 5 neural damage against the single target.

!!__C Class__ 
!!!!Harm IV (dependent i) – SC 10 / Block  1

When you roll to attack a valid target within immediate range of you in a computer system using a cyber terminal or similar gear to execute this program, roll with Smarts. For every success, you deal 7 neural damage.

!!__B Class__ 
!!!!Harm III (dependent I, single target i) – SC 10 / Block  1

When you execute this program using a deck or similar gear, which is required, you target a single digital target of your choice in immediate range, I.e within the same node as you. Roll Smarts. For every success, you deal 9 neural damage against the single target.

!!__A Class__ 
!!!!Harm V (dependent i) – SC 17 / Block  1

When you roll to attack a valid target within immediate range of you in a computer system using a cyber terminal or similar gear to execute this program, roll with Smarts. For every success, you deal 11 neural feedback damage.

!!__S Class__ 
!!!!Harm VI (dependent i, single target i) – SC 12 / Block  1

When you execute this program using a deck or similar gear, which is required, you target a single digital target of your choice in immediate range, I.e within the same node as you. Roll Smarts. For every success, you deal 13 neural feedback damage against the single target.

<hr>

!Infernos

Infernos, like scorchers are used to induce harm on digital constructs. While Scorchers are used to destabilize a small number of systems, infernos inject harmful data in a sibgle node to harm all other users or net presences in the node.  Below are common examples and class of infernos, where each can only be used by a terminal, cyberdeck or similar gear item under the control of a user.

!!__B Class__ 
!!!!Harm VI (dependent i, area of effect i, shaped i) – SC 7 / Block  1

When you execute this program using a deck or similar gear, you target every digital target except yourself within immediate range i.e within the same node as you. Roll Smarts. For every success, you deal 3 neural feedback damage.

!!__A Class__ 
!!!!Harm II (dependent i, area of effect i, shaped i) – SC 14 / Block  1

When you execute this program using a deck or similar gear, you target every digital target except yourself within immediate range i.e within the same node as you. Roll Smarts. For every success, you deal 5 neural feedback damage.

!!__S Class__ 
!!!!Harm III (dependent i, area of effect i, shaped i) – SC 21 / Block  2

When you execute this program using a deck or similar gear, you target every digital target except yourself within immediate range i.e within the same node as you. Roll Smarts. For every success, you deal 7 neural feedback damage.

<hr>

!Breakers
Breakers are programs that circumvent or pass through firewalls. They reduce the difficulty of gaining access to protected computer systems and increases the chances of not being identified as an unauthorized access. Unfortunately, breakers often have a limited number of uses due to the learning nature of some firewalls. As breakers are used, the chances of success are reduced as the firewalls learns, adapts, and overcome the effectiveness of the breaker. the Street Cred cost of these programs reflect the cost of staying up to date and closer to the edge.


!!__D Class__ 
!!!!Barrier Bypass I (dependent i) – SC 4 / Block  1

When you roll to bypass a firewall and you use this program to do so, ignore 1 burn. This program must be inserted or otherwise be used with a terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__D+ Class__
!!!!{Barrier Bypass I, Concealment I} (dependent i) – SC 11 / Block 1
When you roll to bypass a firewall and you use this program to do so, ignore/reduce the burn by 1. On a failure, the firewall takes 1 burn to successfully flag you. This program must be inserted or otherwise be used with a terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__C Class__
!!!!Barrier Bypass II  (dependent i) – SC 9/ Block 1
When you roll to bypass a firewall and you use this program to do so, ignore/reduce the burn by 2. This program must be inserted or otherwise be used with a terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__C+ Class__
!!!!{Barrier Bypass II, Concealment I} (dependent i) – SC 16 / Block 1
When you roll to bypass a firewall and you use this program to do so, ignore/reduce the burn by 2. On a failure, the firewall takes 1 burn to successfully flag you. This program must be inserted or otherwise be used with a terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__B Class__
!!!!Barrier Bypass III (dependent i) – SC 14 / Block 1
When you roll to bypass a firewall and you use this program to do so, ignore/reduce the burn by 3.  This program must be inserted or otherwise be used with a terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__B+ Class__
!!!!{Barrier Bypass III, Concealment I} (dependent i) – SC 21 / Block 2
When you roll to bypass a firewall and you use this program to do so, ignore/reduce the burn by 3. On a failure, the firewall takes 1 burn to successfully flag you. This program must be inserted or otherwise be used with a terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__B++ Class__
!!!!{Barrier Bypass III, Concealment II} (dependent i) - SC 25 / Block 2
When you roll to bypass a firewall and you use this program to do so, ignore/reduce the burn by 3. On a failure, the firewall takes 2 burn to successfully flag you. This program must be inserted or otherwise be used with a terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

<hr>

!Freezers
A freezer is any program that disrupts or interrupts the digital communication between a digital target and the system at large. The means of accomplishing this could be flooding the target with harmless information so that it no longer can process in a timely manner, or it might be severing the communication between a subject and others. Either way, the target cannot take in new information, but still processes. This amounts to temporarily blinding and deafening a person without removing their ability to act or speak.

!!__D Class__
!!!!De-link I (dependent) – 7 SC / Block 1
This cassette contains a program that overwhelms the input of a system and temporarily disrupts communication to it. This caused the system or target to operate blindly. You target digital targets within immediate range and roll Smarts. On a success the target no longer receives digital input for 1 minute or until they gain 1 success on a roll to re-establish input, whichever comes first. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__C Class__
!!!!De-link II (dependent) –  14 SC / Block 1	
This cassette contains a program that overwhelms the input of a system and temporarily disrupts communication to it. This caused the system or target to operate blindly. You target digital targets within immediate range and roll Smarts. On a success the target no longer receives digital input for 1 minute or until they gain 2 successes on a roll to re-establish input, whichever comes first. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__B Class__
!!!!De-link III (dependent) –  21 SC / Block 2	
This cassette contains a program that overwhelms the input of a system and temporarily disrupts communication to it. This caused the system or target to operate blindly. You target digital targets within immediate range and roll Smarts. On a success the target no longer receives digital input for 1 minute or until they gain 3 successes on  a roll to re-establish input, whichever comes first. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__A Class__
!!!De-link IV (dependent) –  28 SC / Block 2
This cassette contains a program that overwhelms the input of a system and temporarily disrupts communication to it. This caused the system or target to operate blindly. You target digital targets within immediate range and roll Smarts. On a success the target no longer receives digital input for 1 minute or until they gain 4 successes on a roll to re-establish input, whichever comes first. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

<hr>

!Icicles
''Icicles'' are focused freezers that can target only one net target at a time. They sacrifice versatility for focused junk data at a lower cost point. They still disrupt communication to a net target by injecting raw data to overwhelm processing, leaving a net element operationally blind to new input.

!!__D Class__
!!!!De-link I (dependent, single target) –  4 SC / Block 1	
This cassette contains a program that overwhelms the input of a single system and temporarily disrupts communication to it. This caused the system or target to operate blindly. You targets single digital targets within immediate range and roll Smarts. On a success the target no longer receives digital input for 1 minute or until they gain 1 success on a roll to re-establish input, whichever comes first. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__C Class__
!!!!De-link II (dependent, single target) –  8 SC / Block 1	
This cassette contains a program that overwhelms the input of a single system and temporarily disrupts communication to it. This caused the system or target to operate blindly. You targets single digital targets within immediate range and roll Smarts. On a success the target no longer receives digital input for 1 minute or until they gain 2 successes on a roll to re-establish input, whichever comes first. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__B Class__
!!!!De-link III (dependent, single target) –  12 SC / Block 1	
This cassette contains a program that overwhelms the input of a single system and temporarily disrupts communication to it. This caused the system or target to operate blindly. You targets single digital targets within immediate range and roll Smarts. On a success the target no longer receives digital input for 1 minute or until they gain 3 successes on a roll to re-establish input, whichever comes first. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__A Class__
!!!!De-link IV (dependent, single target) – 16 SC / Block 1	
This cassette contains a program that overwhelms the input of a single system and temporarily disrupts communication to it. This caused the system or target to operate blindly. You targets single digital targets within immediate range and roll Smarts. On a success the target no longer receives digital input for 1 minute or until they gain 4 successes on a roll to re-establish input, whichever comes first. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

<hr>

!Blizzards
The "Frak this!" program for cowboys in a pinch. A blizzard delivers an indiscriminate volume of junk data inside a single net node, affecting all net targets except the users PAN. cowboys and hotdoggers use them alike to buy time to get out or to finish a job.

!!__D Class__
!!!!De-link I (dependent, area of effect, shaped i) –  14 SC / Block 1	
This cassette contains a program that overwhelms the input of multiple systems with in a node, temporarily disrupting communication to them. This caused the system or target to operate blindly. You target all digital targets within immediate range besides yourself and roll Smarts. On a success the target no longer receives digital input for 1 minute or until they gain 1 success on a roll to re-establish input, whichever comes first. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.


!!__C Class__
!!!!De-link II (dependent, area of effect, shaped i) –  28 SC / Block 2
This cassette contains a program that overwhelms the input of multiple systems with in a node, temporarily disrupting communication to them. This caused the system or target to operate blindly. You target all digital targets within immediate range besides yourself and roll Smarts. On a success the target no longer receives digital input for 1 minute or until they gain 2 successes on a roll to re-establish input, whichever comes first. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__B Class__
!!!!De-link III (dependent, area of effect, shaped i) – 42 SC / Block 4
This cassette contains a program that overwhelms the input of multiple systems with in a node, temporarily disrupting communication to them. This caused the system or target to operate blindly. You target all digital targets within immediate range besides yourself and roll Smarts. On a success the target no longer receives digital input for 1 minute or until they gain 3 successes on a roll to re-establish input, whichever comes first. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

<hr>

!Halts
Halts are any program that are designed to inhibit another programs or digital targets from executing. It could be by prompting a daemon to force end a specific program or preying on a vulnerability in a particular program. Halts are often used to either stop a program from executing or to end a program currently in use. In order to use the program again, the target must be fixed by its user, often taking up time and attention better used in resolving the security breach in the network. Targetable programs include implicit ones, such as programs that allow movement in VR or copy files to memory.

!!__Class D__
!!!!Entrap Ip (dependent, single target I) – 1 SC / Block 1

This cassette contains a program that interrupts and halts the execution of an ongoing, continuous effect or digital element for 1 minute. This program can also stop programs from being able to be run. This includes instantaneous digital effects. If the Halt is successful against a continuous effect, the effect is paused for the duration of the halt. The halt ends after 1 minute has elapsed or if the user rolls 1 success to overcome the entrap.The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.


!!__Class C__
!!!!Entrap IIp (dependent, single target I) – 2 SC / Block 1

This cassette contains a program that interrupts and halts the execution of an ongoing, continuous effect or digital element for 1 minute. This program can also stop programs from being able to be run. This includes instantaneous digital effects. If the Halt is successful against a continuous effect, the effect is paused for the duration of the halt. The halt ends after 1 minute has elapsed or if the user rolls 2 success to overcome the entrap.The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__Class B__
!!!!Entrap IIIp (dependent, single target I) – 3 SC / Block 1

This cassette contains a program that interrupts and halts the execution of an ongoing, continuous effect or digital element for 1 minute. This program can also stop programs from being able to be run. This includes instantaneous digital effects. If the Halt is successful against a continuous effect, the effect is paused for the duration of the halt. The halt ends after 1 minute has elapsed or if the user rolls 3 success to overcome the entrap.The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__Class A__
!!!!Entrap IVp (dependent, single target I) – 4 SC / Block 1

This cassette contains a program that interrupts and halts the execution of an ongoing, continuous effect or digital element for 1 minute. This program can also stop programs from being able to be run. This includes instantaneous digital effects. If the Halt is successful against a continuous effect, the effect is paused for the duration of the halt. The halt ends after 1 minute has elapsed or if the user rolls 4 success to overcome the entrap.The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__Class S__
!!!!Entrap Vp (dependent, single target I) – 6 SC / Block 1

This cassette contains a program that interrupts and halts the execution of an ongoing, continuous effect or digital element for 1 minute. This program can also stop programs from being able to be run. This includes instantaneous digital effects. If the Halt is successful against a continuous effect, the effect is paused for the duration of the halt. The halt ends after 1 minute has elapsed or if the user rolls 5 success to overcome the entrap.The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

<hr>

!Blockers
''Blockers'' are are portable firewalls that protect clusters of programs all registered in the same PAN. They protect a user on the Net and all the programs that they have activated from other antagonistic cowboys and InfoSec officers. Their mobility does come with some draw backs. They do need to be activated and they themselves can be subject to an attack such as from a Halt program. However, they are common in the usage of cyber combat and appear commonly as colored crystal globes that surround the user in VR and Deep in the Net.

!!__Class C__
!!!!Barrier I (dependent) – 7 SC / Block 1
This cassette contains a program that serves as a barrier to block digital threats from passing through to a PAN from a larger network. All net actions or digital effects that target you or net elements in your PAN suffer 1 burn. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.


!!__Class B__
!!!!Barrier II (dependent) – 14 SC / Block 1
This cassette contains a program that serves as a barrier to block digital threats from passing through to a PAN from a larger network. All net actions or digital effects that target you or net elements in your PAN suffer 2 burn. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

!!__Class A__
!!!!Barrier II (dependent) – 21 SC / Block 2
This cassette contains a program that serves as a barrier to block digital threats from passing through to a PAN from a larger network. All net actions or digital effects that target you or net elements in your PAN suffer 3 burn. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

<hr>

!Dampeners
Programs that are ''Dampeners'' generate motes of data that adsorb harmful digital information. They surround the user and intercept any digital attack, allowing themselves to be cannibalized in place of their user. In this way, Dampeners serve as digital armor against neural damage a user would normally experience.The higher class dampeners produce a greater number of digital motes

Class D
Armor I (dependent i) – 3 SC / Block 1
This cassette contains a program that protects against digital threats against a PAN. When activated, the user reduces all neural damage by 3 per attackers success. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.


Class C
Armor II (dependent i) – 7 SC / Block 1
This cassette contains a program that protects against digital threats against a PAN. When activated, the user reduces all neural damage by 5 per attackers success. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

Class B
Armor III (dependent i) – 10 SC / Block 1
This cassette contains a program that protects against digital threats against a PAN. When activated, the user reduces all neural damage by 7 per attackers success. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

Class A
Armor IV (dependent i) – 14 SC / Block 1
This cassette contains a program that protects against digital threats against a PAN. When activated, the user reduces all neural damage by 9 per attackers success. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.

|!Class S | !17 SC / 1 Block|
|Armor V (dependent i) |<|
|This cassette contains a program that protects against digital threats against a PAN. When activated, the user reduces all neural damage by 11 per attackers success. The program requires being slotted into and used with a data terminal or cyberdeck in order to be used.|<|






''Cyberpunk'' is a style dedicated to the expressing the alienation from one’s own sense of humanity.  While such alienation might usually be a symptom of a psychological disturbance, a Cyberpunk accepts and appeals to their desire to surpass their normal limitation to discover their true humanity or self.  The style distorts the natural human aspects of music, fashion, and social hierarchy.  These DIY cyberneticists create a distinct mechanical or chrome appearance as they continue to improve upon nature.

The style and the effects of their cybernetics suppresses a cyberpunk’s facial and vocal expressions due the associated suppression of their emotional.  The way that a cyberpunk instead expresses themselves is through weaving bioelectronics, neon, and luminal effects into their more robotic form.

This street fashion and transhumanist style rose both as a street fashion and a pseudo-intellectual venture.  However, the largest cyberpunk concepts were adopted by the disenfranchised and criminal elements who relied on older cyberware and gear to accomplish unique feats not intended by manufacturers







''Cyberspace'' is the graphic and geometric representation of digital information hosted by every computer and node in the Net. While [[VR|Virtual Reality]] allows access and tangible manipulation of data from inside the node, cyberspace is the most direct sensory stimulation of the human mind using digital information. 

Considered by many as a dangerous method of accessing data, cyberspace allows for a consciousness nearly independent of the human body. While sensory accounts of cyberspace differ, it has been confirmed that two persons in Cyberspace often experience the same hallucinatory experiences of lights, voices, and lines of data organized in folding and ever-expanding constellations.

While VR has constructs that help communicate the purpose of a program or a piece of data, cyberspace does not have that luxury. Instead, a runner or infosec officer must be able to intuitively locate information by interfacing heavily with the computer system. The greater or more successful the integration the easier it is to understand the data and the less likely the user is to be stunned or disoriented due to integration sickness.

While in cyberspace, a user is virtually free to move and explore almost any information except those behind firewalls or that which is protected by Intrusive Countermeasures or “Ice”. Ice can do anything from booting you out of the system, to providing biofeedback to make you leave. Some Ice will quarantine you until an ~InfoSec office can come by and get a good look at you.







Cyberware is that good tech of neon and chrome that you put into your body. It’s what can improve your natural abilities or give you knew ones which are directly plugged into your neural system. Cyberware can give a number of fantastical abilities, but past the dark future, most of them are for convenience or style. 

Cyberware could be eyes that let you record from your perspective and save to a memory cache in your head, dermal implants that protect factory workers from damage to their hands, skin to make you burn proof. But cyberware is also artificial hair that glows like neon and changes colors, tattoos that are animated under your skin, or a digital assistant that that schedules your life to make things easier for you. Cyberware is a fashion and lifestyle choice that makes everyone better and more stylish.

!!Renegade Cost
Cyberware has an additional cost to it besides [[Street Cred]]. Every person has a renegade spirit that allows them to break the mold the system has for them or even the system itself. It’s this spirit that a machine does not have, and which we lose as we slowly replace ourselves with more and more machines. During character creation, a character has a [[Renegade Score]] of 100. As more cyberware is installed, the score is reduced by the renegade cost of all cyberware. 

The Renegade cost associated with cyberware gear is the Street Cred Cost divides by 5. However, the minimum renegade cost of any cyberware is 1. Subtract the cost from your current Renegade Points at the time the cyberware is installed, not necessarily when it is purchased.

!!Bioware
A specialized and highly restricted new form of cyberware has not yet hit the market. It's a less invasive alternative to cyberware, but has an increased cost. ''Bioware'' augments the bodies own natural abilities instead of replacing body parts with machinery. such as a liver able to filter out poisons and toxins, are super powered adrenal glands to aid in a burst of power during combat. Some of this in development gear also allows bodies to have cells from other animals graphed into it. Such as an electric eel's shocking cells, or the rough skin of a shark.

The renegade cost associated with bioware gear is the Street Cred cost divided by 10, but the Street cred cost is 50% more. Calculate the renegade loss before taking into account the increased street cred cost.






!!__Cyber-arm__	
Extra Limb I -- 15 SC (3 RS)

Congratulations on acquiring your own chrome cybernetic arm, either as a replacement or for additional functionality. The arm once registered to your PAN behaves and functions as any other arm you may posses. the limb is no stronger or dexterous than it's natural counterpart, and if it replaces a limb, it removes any penalties associated with that loss. The renegade score cost of the cyber arm is 3.

!! __Strong Arm__
Extra Limb I, Enhance ability I (alter time ix) -- 68 SC (13 RS)

Nothing more cyberpunk than losing an arm just to replace it with stronger and improved tech. This cyberlimb functions like the more basic variety except that the arm increases the athletic ability of the adopter indefinitely. The adopter increases their modified Athletics score by 1. The adopter loses this modified score improvement should the Limb be disabled, lost or otherwise removed from functioning. The renegade score cost for this cybernetic is 13.

!! __Dermal Plating__
Armor I (x3) -- 15 SC (3 RS)

Small plates of metallic ceramic composite are implanted under the skin allowing for increased protection against physical damage. A person with these implants installed may not be readily visible at the inattentive glance, but are whenever someone looks at them. They create blocky and distorted shapes underneath the skin, leading to a robotic or other-humanly appearance. When a person with this cyberware installed takes crushing, slashing, or piercing damage they reduce the damage by 2 for every success of the attackers attack. The renegade score cost for this cyberware is 3.

!! __Neural Jack__	
Jack I -- 5 SC (1 RS)

This cyberware allows for the communication between the users brain and digital interfaces, like other cyberware, data terminals, and their PAN. When using this device to communicate in such a manner, you can communicate with any device within immediate range with a similar brain-user interface or in your PAN. This communication can be via jacks, interfaced cybernetics, but also via use of the wireless Near-Me™ band. The renegade score cost of this gear is 1.

!! __Fast Jack__	
Jack I, Communication II -- 11 SC (2 RS)

Able to communicate information between brain and digital interfaces at twice the speeds, a fast jack is considered the upgrade to the common neural jack. It functions just as a Neural Jack, but the speed of which it does it twice as fast. The renegade score cost of this gear is 2.

!! __Reflex Booster__
Aid I (x2) -- 10 (2)

Capable of providing a temporary increase in reflex speeds, this implant is often used by SWAT teams and TacSec teams before breaching doors or engaging in fire fights. Once activated as a quick action, the user has edge on initiative rolls and doge rolls for one minute. The renegade score cost of this gear is 2.







Corporation Names
Corporation names are various, numerous and are often times easily confused with one another. A corporate name like an edgerunner’s is a brand and a face to those. Below are a list of used and unused corporate names that do business in the Texaplex. Use them as inspiration or names of actual corporations that you characters interact with or do business with.

!A-M
Accelerate, Amergy, America State, Autonation, Badeon, Bastion, Bed Banks, Ceasology, ~CutriSec, Cybergy,  diVersolutions, Dollor Korp, Dr Hort’s, Excelleration, FMC Corp, Genergy, Homesync, Invescorp, Jaeger-Seif International, Kilgore Munitions, L3 Inc, Mater Corp, ~McCorp, ~McDeal Corp, Mic Services, Mohawk Ink, M&T Corp

!N-Z
Natralife, Nisoh, Oí’ll Inc, Orgraimic, Peoplesync, Ppl Co, Progressing Genomics, Public Co, Q (Kyū), Ray Corp  Sandco, Theo Corp, The Apple Group, The Bay Incorporated, The HER Group, TJX Corp, United Aviation, United Ionics, ~ViruaKinetics, ~WasteNergy, Xpres, Xylion, Yum Great







Referred to commonly as “the Metroplex,” or “DFW,” its population is a hefty 13 million and is the cultural and financial hub of the northern Texaplex. DFW is by far the tallest of the metropolitan area and boasts blocks that have a water front view on its many artificial lakes and rivers. To the North where I-35W and I-35E join together again is the city of Denton which serves as the northern point of the Texaplex. DFW is also noteworthy of completely surrounding the landlocked [[Independent City of Texia]].

Many industries and megacorporations are headquartered in or have major bases of operations in the DFW, Dallas in particular. 74 of the Top 500 Corporations are headquartered in DFW. DFW itself is the birth place of 3 of the Big 12: Texas Instruments, Agrifoodstuffs, and Exxon Mobile. DFW is also home to 2 airports and 1 spaceport, the Dallas Cowboys, Texas Rangers, Dallas Mavericks, Cowtown Brawl, among various other professional sports teams. 

!!Dallas
The land which Dallas is built on is mostly flat, but it boasts some of the tallest skyscrapers in the Texaplex. It is also home to historic cathedrals and the Catholic Church owns a subsidiary embassy of it's own in Dallas. It is also home to a vast number of museums about history, art, culture, and science within it's Art Deco designed Art District.

Today, it's business is mostly comprised of financial, communications and [[Net|The Net]] infrastructure companies. It's is home to what is refered to as [[NetComm Corridor]], northern suburb home to over 1000 Net communication companies. It's Financial businesses are commonly aligned with the interests of Chinese and Nipponese businesses and manufactures, and both China and Nippon have embassies within downtown Dallas. It is home to both the former Federal Reserve Bank and the Dallas World Trade Center.

Dallas is served by ''DART,'' the Dallas Area Rapid Transit, a privatized company which operates buses, light rail, and commuter rail systems through Dallas and virtually all of it's suburban areas. It is the longest rail system in the entire world, but isn't it's busiest. It has seen a recent increase in use due to an influx of [[Bay City]] and [[San Angeles]] Corpo transplants.

!!Fort Worth
Deriving it's name from a pre- American Civil War US fort that overlooked the Trinity River, Fort Worth became transformed once it became a logistical hub for food, livestock, and gold. It was the historical center of the Texas Longhorde cattle trade, which earned it's moniker ''"Cowtown."'' Today, it still maintains a Frontier Western and Nova-Western architecture more than any other city in the Texaplex and hosts the largest number of pieces of western/cowboy art in the world.

Fort worth is the location of several defense, aerospace, and transportation corporations today. This list include Lockeed Martin Corporation, Pier 1 Exports, and American Airlines. It is also home to a number of gas wells, and energy facilities that are connected through gas lines to Houston. Fort Worth also serves as the headquarters of the [[The Sundays Foundation]] and other traditionalist political clubs and.







During play, should there be a time in which there are no [[Foci]] that are appropriate, roll for success as if it was for an untrained Focus. Should there be a time during play where there is not a clear key [[Ability|Abilities]] to roll, the GM should choose the closest Ability instead, which might be [[Luck]].







Denims is a style adopted by youth movements arguing for a post-industrial and anti-establishment social order.  Noted for their rejection if not apathetic approach to current social structures, they fight for what they deem a good social order.  Their physical appearance and clothing put a focus in natural and non-synthetic goods, clothing, and gear when possible.  Clothing focuses on using natural fabrics and materials and focuses on using technology as a service on not just humanity but also the environment. They focus on recreating or reclaiming the promised world peace from the 1960s and 1970s.

Their gear is often created to be more natural and humanistic in experiences inside an ever more plastic and mass-produced world.  By using psychoactive drugs, and neural algorithms, they augment their brains and nervous systems to handle greater number of experiences and transitory mentalities. This goes on with their adopted forms of music that arise from non-mainstream sources such as jazz, blues, folk, rock, Nova-step fused with influences and instruments from international cultures.







To ''determine success'' of a rolled dice pool, count the number of dice equal to or less than your character's key ability. That is the number of ''Hits'' for the action. The GM or rule will state what the key ability is at the time of [[Creating a Dice Pool]]. Compare the number of Hits to a target given by the GM. This is usually a number between 0 - 4. If you have the same number of hits you succeed, and every additional hit grants an additional effect. 

This additional effect could be almost anything (within narrative reasoning), bu typically comes as doing the task faster, doing additional damage on attacks, or changing the environment. You can also spend additional hits to grant an ally that can see you [[Edge]] or regain [[Style Points]].







In the following subsections, you will learn with more detail how to use your character's skills and abilities to accomplish tasks more about the games rules and mechanics.

* [[The Dice]] - Overview of the dice used and how to use them.
* [[Creating a Dice Pool]] - How to choose the dice required for risky or dramatic actions
* [[Determining Success]] - How to determine how well your character performed an action
* [[Contested Rolls]] - How to determine success between two contested actions
* [[Edge]] - The benefits of an advantageous situation
* [[Burn]] - The detriments of impeding effects or circumstances.
* [[Default Rolling]] - How to roll when your training can't help you.

[[< PREVIOUS|]] | [[ToC|Table of Contents]] | [[NEXT >|]]







Digital gear includes data, accounts, programs, executable or other computer files. This gear is comprised of data that are files and information stored, used, and accessed by terminals and cyber deck. These digital goods take up a resources called memory, the amount of data, which is measured in blocks. The cost of storing the gear in blocks is dependent on the gears [[Street Cred]] cost. Divide the ''SC'' cost of the gear by 10 (minimum of 1) to calculate the number of memory blocks required to store it.

While most digital gear is saved on a cyber terminal or deck, many can be saved to a drive or cassette that can be physically moved in meatspace and slotted into a cyber deck when needed. These cassettes come with their own memory and multiple digital gear can be located on a single cassette that's large enough.

!!Memory

|Apoch-10 |8 |9 |Memory VIII |
|Apoch-10i |9 |10 |Memory IX |
|The Brick mini |14 |15 |Memory XIV |
|The Brick|19 |20 |Memory XIX |

|Class B |3 |1 |Entrap IIIp  (dependent, single target I) |
|Class A |4 |1 |Entrap IVp (dependent, single target I) |
|Class S |6 |1 |Entrap Vp (dependent, single target I) |
|!//Blockers// |<|<|<|
|Class C |7 |1 |Barrier I (dependent) |
|Class B |14 |1 |Barrier II (dependent) |
|Class A |21 |2 |Barrier II (dependent) |
|!//Dampeners// |<|<|<|
|Class D |5 |1 |Amor I |
|Class C |10 |1 |Amor II |
|Class B |15 |1 |Amor III |
|Class A |20 |2 |Amor IV |
|Class S |25 |2 |Amor V |











The commute for most people relies at least on part on transportation of busses, ride-shares, or their own person transportation. For the safety and the speed of the populous, automobiles and roads became built or retrofitted with the ~DriveNet technology. ~DriveNet is a network built that allows for autonomous and collision free transit on the roadways of the Texaplex. It also has increased the speed of transit as the system orchestrated all automobiles allowing for otherwise illegal maneuvers and control. All that a rider has to do is enter or say their desired location and wait as they are sped along to their destination.

~DriveNet has saved countless lives and has allowed the Texaplex economy to grow due to the efficiency it provides. But ~DriveNet is more than a service, it’s a corporation owned by corporations, with the true owner lost somewhere in a web of Hypercorporations. These corps have secrets and places they don’t want people. And at its basis, Drive Net is about controlling people’s movement. If you ever end up on a drive longer than expected, you’ve been controlled. Somewhere there’s a place along the fastest route, where people should go. ~DriveNet might be safe, but it also control what the masses see in a dangerous endgame.







For the players that want custom equipment, these additional rules can serve as a means for the GM and the player to make gear with special purposes or unique to the character's needs.

During creation of custom gear, SC is spent on grouping effects with limitations and expansions that the gear provides its users. Gear is described in general mechanical effects and terms.  It is up to the player to stack and organize the terms and effects to create descriptions of gear.  It is up to the players, especially the GM to verify that the gear makes sense, fits the narrative and won’t spoil the fun or themes of the game, hamper the narrative, or make the game mundane or risk averse. 

!!Gear Metatypes
Some gear belongs to a specialized type, such as a [[Vehicles]], [[Chems]], [[Cyberware]], and [[Digital Gear]] and each has its own rules.

!!Narrative Limitations
With a plethora of effects to choose from, it would be mechanically possible for a person to create a gun that rapid fire shoots grenades that explode and grant armor to those in the explosion of each grenade’s blast.  However, such an item sounds ridiculous albeit cool, and could quickly break the expectations established by the narrative and character backgrounds.  It’s up to the players to police one another and to remark on the ills such strange and fantastical gear would bring to the game.  As GM, it is their focus to ensure such items do not malign the themes and narrative of the game. As such, these players are most responsible for policing the gear of all characters.

!!Calculating Costs
Custom designed gear will cost the sum of the effects of each effect.  Each effect will cost the product of the number of ranks and the cost per rank plus or minus the percentage increase or decrease of the cost, based on the sum of the expansions and limitation. Although the typical cost per rank of the effects should typically by 3-6 SC, the more power effects cost somewhere between 8 and 10 SC per rank. 

The total cost of the item is the sum cost of all it’s effects and any special additional or reduced costs from Expansions and Limitations

Incidental effects or simple one off uses of effects should be allowed for free.  If an effect has no overbearing power over the game or narrative, the game shouldn’t be stopped to formally calculated the additional cost of the gear.  However, if such an effect is continuously used, the effect should be added with an additional cost.

!!Example Calculation
The base cost of effect A is 5 SC, and the gear has 2 ranks in effect A.  the cost modifiers from the expansions and limitations are +0.2 and -0.4.  therefore, the cost for Effect A is: 

```
(5 x 2) + (5x2)(0.2 – 04) or 10 - 2 = 8. 
```

After a bit of algebra, the general formula is:


```
(Ranks x Cost) x (1 + Limitations – Expansions)
```

The 1 represents the base cost (or 100% normal cost) of the ranks and cost per rank.

The gear has 2 other effects, effect B and effect C, which cost 9 and 14.  That means that the final cost for the gear is:

```
 9 + 14 + 8, which is 31 SC.
```

See [[Effects]] For a list of Effects and their costs as well as a small description.

See [[Limitations]] for changes to Effects that decrease their scope but also the cost of the Effect.

See [[Expansions]] for changes to Effects tat increase their scope but also the cost of the Effect.








During play, characters will develop and gain access to new skills as the narrative develops.  To reflect the growth of the characters during play or during narrative, [[Street Cred]] is awarded during the play by all the other players, not just the GM.  The typical amount of Street Cred awarded should be based on the narrative development, the character and players’ exploration of the story and environment, and the number of plot points developed or resolved.  

The GM should award the bulk of the Street Cred, typically 10-15 street cred to each player for the typical 4 to 5 hour game session. The Non-GM players award street cred to the other players based on more personal factors. Each player has 3 points, on which they can use to award street cred.  It is important to explain why you award street cred to your fellow player. Example justifications or areas to award street cred are:

* The player who best role played with your character.
* The player who kept the pace of the game going.
* The player who role played best overall.
* The most creative player or player who showed the greatest ingenuity.
* The players who made the game worth it tonight.

The first point awarded to another player grants 2 street cred, while all consecutive points awarded to the same player grants 1 street cred.







Whenever a character is in an advantageous position or acts with an unquantifiable benefit, increase the number of the dice in the dice pool by one, thus increasing the chances of success. This is ''edge.'' It functions as the opposite of [[Burn]].

Unless explicitly stated otherwise, edge does not stack with other sources of edge.  If a rule allows edge to stack with other edge, those types of edge will be called ''Strong Edge''*.  Because edge normally does not stack, non-Strong edge, called ''weak edge'', will not stack with strong edge.  This means that strong edge will only stack with other strong edge.
//*when using 6-sided dice, edge never stacks, so treat strong edge like weak edge.//







Public education in [[The Texaplex]] was one of the first thing defunded in the light of the economic distress of the 2010s. Public schools soon became non-compulsory after the 7th grade, and those that remained in high school to graduate no longer received a competitive education and often lacked vital resources. This isn’t to say that no one received an education. Instead, only the smartest and richest got into actual schools.

The rich were virtually guaranteed access to the greatest schools based on which ones their families could buy or have legacy. The “middle-class” could get in either through scholarships or by selling their adult life in indentured service to a corporation in exchange to an education. For them, any drop in grades could eliminate their entire hope of a better future. This stress leads to chem addiction or burnout, and it doesn’t matter what the excuse was. Scholarships don’t like giving to addicts, and [[Megacorporations]] don’t always get their return in investment from them. Plus, there are plenty of other desperate kids out there.







Gear is mechanically distinguished by the effects it has, and effects are distinguished by the key words and terminology used in their description. If an effect has one of the following key words in it's description, please refer to the following list to determine what it means. Your GM has say on how different keywords interact.

!!!Concentration
The effect requires the character to continuously use the item and characters cannot use two pieces of gear at the same time that both have this keyword. If a character uses another gear with a concentration requirement, the effects of the previous gear immediately ends. Most effects that have this key word also require a complex action to use. 

!!!Instantaneous
The effect occurs whenever the gear is used or a predetermined triggering event occurs.

!!!Persistent
The effect continues until it's time runs out, it is turned off, or if an end condition (such as a target succeeding on roll) is met. The effect occurs at the very end of an initiative round unless otherwise stated in description of the effect.

!!!Line of Effect
The effect requires an unimpeded line from the gear to the target of the effect through its given medium. A bullet can only hit things which it can travel trough and cybercombat can only effect things connected to the Net. Such key worded effects can suffer from burn due to cover.

!!!Range
The maximum distance from an effect's origin to its target that the effect can reach. Range is best described in bands or ranges

* Self – the effect targets either effects the character using the gear or the gear itself depending on the effect.
* Immediate – The effect can target within arm's reach or swinging range, e.g., within roughly 1 meter of the user.
* Short – The target is between an immediate to a stone throw or short walk away, roughly 7 meters. People in short range of one another can easily hear each other if they talk.
* Medium Range – the targets are several meters away.  People talking must yell, and getting to one another requires a little exertion as they run. Roughly 20 meters, most stones thrown cannot make it this far. Pistols are difficult to use accurately at this range.
* Long range – characters long distances away most yell extremely loudly to communicate and would be better off with a comms system instead.  Pistols are useless at this range, but hunting rifles are worthwhile.  The distance requires either a long run or an exhausting sprint to reach long range.
* Extended range – this range denotes a scale that most people are not going to handle without the use of vehicles or specialized weapons or scanners.  Communication requires a comms system, and weapons are typically scoped and guided for any accuracy.  This distance is routinely measured in terms of blocks.

!!!Shape
for effects that occur within a given area  e.g. has an area of effect. Such effects with a shape also have a coordinating shape. This is given in the following table.

!!!Size
For effects that occur within a given area e.g. has an area of effect, such effects with a size also have a coordinating shape.  This is given in the following table.

|||!Shape|<|<|<|<|<|<|<|<|<|<|<|
|||Cone|Cube|Sphere|Bolt 0|Bolt 1|Bolt 2|
|!Size|1|2|2|1|5|3|1|
|~|2|3|3|1|10|7.5|2|
|~|3|4|3|1.5|25|15|3|
|~|4|5|4|1.5|50|25|5|
|~|5|8|5|2|100|20|10|
|~|6|10|6|2|150|75|20|
|~|7|12|7|3|250|125|30|
|~|8|15|8|3|350|175|40|







''Empathy'' is a measure of a character’s social and intrapersonal acuity.  A character with high empathy can effectively read emotions, intentions, and emotional states.  It does not determine whether your character cares about another. Example activities is determining the likelihood someone is lying to you, calming another person, and identifying social hierarchy of a group. A character able to call bullshit, detect lies or understand others has a high Empathy score.






With the growth of technology, technology has allowed for a broadening of ways to entertain and to 






When your home is a world where you need to fight to survive, or to not be pressed into a gang, the streets develop people who can survive on their own and have had to.  Occasionally, you will need to team up with other runners, but everyone can solo, so be careful who to trust.  The good solo everything, The schmucks duo, those that are too dangerous or desperate trio, and a quartet has 3 disposable members.

The streets are the place where deals are made, and everything is in the shadows of society.  It is always vital to know who to trust up to a price.  There’s a price.  Everyone has a price where they are willing to break contracts and burn chumps.  It’s important to know everyone’s price.







''Exploits'' - also referred to as Talents or Special Skills - are particular things that your character can do that makes them special. They allow your character to do cool and useful things that they normally would not be able to do. They are also the easiest example of how specific rules beat generic rules, as they allow your character to break the rules that all other characters are bound by. 

Exploits typically come from two different sources: [[Character Archetypes]] and Unique [[Gear]] that the [[GM|Being a Game Master]] provides. Often times though, an Exploit requires the expenditure of either [[Style Points]] or [[Street Cred]]. This will be noted in the body of text in the Exploit's description. Should two Exploits be used at the same time and break the same rule in different ways, ask your GM to clarify which one has precedence.






After the players have decided on their Player Character's [[Character Concept|Character Concepts]], but before they spend [[Street Cred]] on customization may be a good time for all the players to pause and work together to decide and develop [[The Block|Blocks]] or local area their character's will spend most of their time in.

The following rules and guides in this section are optional.  If you are looking for a reoccurring game with a story about the development of the characters, or just like detailed settings and creating shared settings and world, then I urge you to at least read the following section. [[CHROMODROME]] is just as much a game about the world as it is the player’s characters. And do not worry, the guide below will not have you populating every store front and office.

Instead ''Block Generation'' focuses on developing the venues and [[Non Player Characters]] special or important to your characters and to help connect PCs together. The Block is the assumed default setting, but it could easily be a urban neighborhood, a squatter packed and abandoned shopping mall, or even a large cluster of shipping containers that are used as housing.

Finally you do not need to flesh out every detail. In fact, I recommend that you keep it to short punchy notes and let everything else flesh out during play. Sometimes just having a name is good enough to start playing.

"""
Step 1 – [[Choose a Locale]]
Step 2 – [[Say Proper Nouns]]
Step 3 – [[Choose Themes]]
Step 4 – [[Places and Faces]]
Step 5 – [[Create a Biz]]
Step 6 – [[Ready the Threat]]
"""








A focus - the singular form of foci - is a cluster of actions and special knowledge that describes a genre of actions.  A focus inherently describes a grouping of actions and knowledge based on the name of the focus itself.  Some are clear, while others are vague or poetic.  Many of the foci will overlap.  This is intended to allow a player to be open in their decision making and providing ample opportunity to allow the character multiple means of acting.

A focus can have multiple meanings as well.  For example, light weapons not only describe a character’s effectiveness with light weapons (ranged or otherwise), but also possibly how to maintain light weapons, where to buy them, or where a light weapon was produced or manufactured.  By leaving the focus without a description, the focus has the players rhetorically define what the focus is and what it applies to for themselves, and most importantly for their character.

!! Common Foci
What follows is an non exhaustive listing of foci, which should cover the typical game session. Should there be a focus not listed below that is readily used at your table during play, discuss adding and workshopping it with your table.

//Books, Brawl, Case, Computers, Deceive, Dodge, Drive, Finagle, Interface, Killswitch, Netrunning, Provoke, Repair, Run, Security, Skulduggery, Sleuth, Stunts, Trauma, Weapons(Heavy), Weapons(light), Wipe.//

!! Ranking
Foci are ranked based on the level of training that a character has in that foci. In ascending order, a focus can be ranked as either untrained, basic, moderate or expert. The rank of the focus determines the starting number of dice in a die pool when taking an action encompassed by a focus, as recorded in the table below.

|!Ranking |!Starting Dice Pool Size |
|Untrained |2 |
|Basic |3 |
|Moderate |4 |
|Expert |5 |

!! Choosing a Focus
Most people would agree that a 9mm pistol or a kitchen knife is a light weapon, and that a Gatling gun is a heavy weapon.  But what about a bastard sword, or a .50 caliber rifle?  The answer is what does it mean to your character and the narrative of the game.  A four-foot-tall person is possibly going to approach a given weapon as a heavy weapon, that a giant character might use as a light weapon.  Whichever way you intend for your character to use a focus, it is important to remain consistent in the usage.
These are some of the many things to think about, share with, and talk about with your table.  






Just as stories and narratives are written around themes and criticized for living up to and explaining an experience built upon those themes, so should games.  The most important of the themes that I focused on and wanted my friends to play and explore are listed in bold italic letters below.  I’ve also included my own thoughts that emerged from each themes’ interactions with each other.

* [[Style Over Substance]]
* [[Everyone Can Solo]]
* [[All Power to the Punks]]
* [[Beat the Machine]]






''Gear'' is the main means for your character to surpass their natural abilities. Gear can come in a variety of forms such as [[Vehicles]], [[Cyberware and Bioware|Cyberware]], [[Combat]], [[Utility]], [[Digital Gear]] and many more. See the [[Gear Catalog]] for a listing of all the pre-generated gear that characters can buy either off the street or in a store. It's there to speed character generation. If you feel brave, see [[Gear Generation]] on how to create your own gear, possibly unique to your character.

!!Acquiring Gear

Each gear item has a [[SC|Street Cred]] cost associated with them. The cost represents not just the costs of acquiring gear for the first time but also maintaining and replacing the gear should it be lost during a job. Gear is either bought, created, or otherwise acquired though play. If you come across some gear during a job, you might be able to purchase the gear for permanent use, typically at the a rate of 7 tenths (x0.7) of the SC cost of the item.

The SC cost of gear listed under the typical equipment for a character's starting archetype costs seven tenths (x0.7) it's usual cost. This reduction is only applicable during character creation.

!!Key Terminology

Gear is mechanically described by type, target, range, effect and other keywords and special abilities on top of style and cost. Gear will have special keywords that have meanings as further described below.  It’s important to understand what they mean so as to accurately reflect the gear’s effects and powers during play.

!!!Effect
A gear's ''Effect'' is what it causes to happen when it is used.  It is synonymous to a exploits description.  The gear effect will describe what rules to follow and what dice to roll, if any are requires.  The effect will often provide a rule that contradicts previous rules follow the main mechanic of few rules, many exceptions when contradictions arise. Gear can and most likely will have multiple effects that often work simultaneously.

!!!Instantaneous
The effect occurs when the gear is used. Most gear has instantaneous effects, particularly weapons.

!!!Concentration
The effect requires the use of a complex action on each turn for the item to be continued to be used. If the character uses another gear that requires a complex action, the effect from this gear ends. Vehicles often require concentration to maintain control of the vehicle during action sequences.

!!!Persistant
The effect continues until one of the described end conditions occurs. these are most common in environmental effects.

!!!Line-of-effect
The effect can only target that which there is an unimpeded line from the target from the effect's origin. effects with line-of-effect.

!!!Range
''Range'' is the distance from the effects origin a target that it can effect. Range is handled in general bands of distance. In increasing range of distance:

|!Range |!Description |
|Self |The target is either the character handling the gear or the gear itself |
|Immediate |The Target is valid if it is within arm's reach or swinging range of the gear. This is roughly 1-2 meters. |
|Short |The target is between immediate and a stone's throw or short walk away, roughly 7 meters. People in short range can easily hear each other while they talk. |
|Medium |The targets are several meters away.  People talking must yell, and getting to one another requires a little exertion as they run. Roughly 20 meters, most stones thrown cannot make it this far. Pistols are difficult to use accurately at this range. |
|Long |Characters long distances away most yell extremely loudly to communicate and would be better off with a comms system instead.  Pistols are useless at this range, but hunting rifles are worthwhile.  The distance requires either a long run or an exhausting sprint to reach long range. |
|Extended |This range denotes a scale that most people are not going to handle without the use of vehicles or specialized weapons or scanners.  Communication requires a comms system, and weapons are typically scoped and guided for any accuracy.  This distance is routinely measured in terms of blocks. |

!!!Area-of-effect
Some effects target all targets within a given area from the effects origin as given by their shape and size. This allows some gear to effect multiple characters or targets at once. The area of effect is determined by it's shape and a given dimension: There are 6 shapes: Cone, Cube, Sphere and Bolts 0, 1, 2.

|!Shape |!Description |
|Cone |A cone extends in a direction you choose from it's origin the distance provided. The cone has a diameter equal to it's distance provided. The effect's point of origin is not considered within the cone unless otherwise specified. |
|Cube |A cube's size is determined by the length of it's edges. it's edges are equal in length to the dimension provided. The origin of a cube has to be somewhere on the surface of the cube. |
|Sphere |A sphere radiates out from the its origin and has a radius of length equal to the dimension given for it's size. |
|Bolt |A bolt follows an uninterrupted line from it's point of origin to another point up to the dimension given away. Bolt 0 effect only the targets which the line travels through, Bolt 0 effects only the targets within 1 meter of the line, and Bolt 2 effects targets only with 2 meters of the line. |

| *As size increases or decrees, go up or down a cell on the table. |c
| !Size* |<|!Cone |!Cube |!Sphere |!Bolt 0 |!Bolt 1 |!Bolt 2 |
|1| ~10m^^3^^| 2| 2| 1| 5| 3| 1|
|2| ~20m^^3^^| 3| 3| 1| 10| 7.5| 2|
|3| ~40m^^3^^| 4| 3| 1.5| 25| 15| 3|
|4| ~80m^^3^^| 5| 4| 1.5| 50| 25| 5|
|5| ~160m^^3^^| 8| 5| 2| 100| 50| 10|
|6| ~250m^^3^^| 10| 6| 2| 150| 75| 20|
|7| ~370m^^3^^| 12| 7| 3| 250| 125| 30|
|8| ~500m^^3^^| 15| 8| 3| 350| 175| 40|


!!Gear Limitations
Gear after character creation must be explained narrative. The most common way for you to acquire gear is through the use of one of your contacts or your foci. The most generic gear you could buy off any street vendor and come with no [[style|Character Styles]] attached to it, but some items are so specialized or rare that it may take some special contact or having a large enough SC score to curry favor with the sellers or manufacturers. and these more difficult to acquire items may bear the style of it's creator or your own.

With a plethora of effects to choose from, it would be mechanically possible for a person to create a gun that rapid fire shoots grenades that explode and grant armor to those in the explosion of each grenade’s blast.  However, such an item sounds ridiculous albeit cool, and could quickly break the expectations established by the narrative and character backgrounds.  It’s up to the players to police one another and to remark on the ills such strange and fantastical gear would bring to the game.  As GM, it is their focus to ensure such items do not malign the themes and narrative of the game. As such, these players are most responsible for policing the gear of all characters.

!!Selling Gear
If you wish to no longer have your current gear, you can exchange the item for 70% it's listed  SC cost.

!!Targeting Gear
Sometimes an effect will target not the user, but the gear itself. This is very common in cybercombat wear a cowboy's terminal or deck becomes fried by IC attacks. It's also common in shoot-outs while driving vehicles, where the attackers punch a few bullet holes into a van's paneling. In the instances where the gear is targeted, a character may expend [[Style Points]] to reduce the damage the gear receives in the same way they would do to reduce damage they themselves would receive. If not enough SP is used to reduce the damage to zero, the gear is inoperable until repaired.






Refer to [[Spending Street Cred]] and [[Gear]] for information on acquiring gear.

The streets of [[The Texaplex]] are lined and filled with storefronts and back alley boutiques of all kinds. The various neighborhoods and suburbs are filled with various styles and races. [[Corpos]] fashion houses line the streets on downtown shopping areas, [[Punkeis]] boutiques advertise from the apartment balconies of blocks, and Cyberpunk clubs have a back door to black body shop for on the spot augmentation and work. Almost anything is attainable in [[The Texaplex]]. Most of it requires some in or a big enough [[Street Cred]], but the following sections and catalogs have the easiest to acquire gear.

For a [[Jobber|Jobber]], having access to the tools of the trade and the right gear for a job is tantamount to survival. You can only go so far with your personal 'edge' or natural talent before someone else with reflex boosters, thermal optics, and a faster terminal get calls to the job you're under prepared for.

You decide how you acquired your gear. It may be from the remnants of your previous life, or something that fell off the back of the truck while you were just standing there. You also decide what sort of style your gear is if it has any. Some gear has universal appeal, like mirror shades and leather, While others are so linked to a certain style that a person might find it difficult to use, such as a pop-pink sub-machine gun being used by a goth, or chrome finished cars being driven by denims


!!Gear Metatypes

!!![[Cyberware]]
''Cyberware'' is the technology of machines fused with the biological flesh, first dreamed up as cyborgs of kitschy sci-fi films of the previous millennia. Almost any gear can be fabricated as cyberware today, not just the myoelecytric prosthesis it originated as.  


!!![[Chems]]
''Chems'' are drugs, even if that term is no longer //en vogue.// There are still the same that always been around, but there are some new varieties, like nova-cocaine, zarathustrian hash, and space mushrooms and designer drugs like bliss, radiation and amp. Each has the ability to form dependencies, but jobbers use chems for situational advantages.


!!![[Digital]]
''Digital'' gear does not exist as a physical item on it's, although it may be stored in a physical medium such as a cassette, a mnemonic device, or as a file on a terminal. It's used in [[The Net]] or in a digital server. As such, it requires a number of memory blocks to store, just like any digital information. Divide the [[Street Cred]] cost of the gear by 10 (minimum of 1) to calculate the number of memory blocks required to store it.


!!Combat
Things will get hairy on the streets, and the same is no different on a job. For this reason, every jobber has to have some means of defending themselves or taking out their opposition. The following catalogs hold a host of weapons and protections while on the street or while doing a job in the real.


!!![[Cosmetic Catalog]]
Just because you are born that way doesn't mean you have to stay that way. Just as almost any part of your body can be replaced by manufactured goods, so can beauty boutiques and tattoo parlors change your appearance.  Cosmetic items typically deal with changes to the actual body for appearances, such as covering chrome or cyberware with natural looking skin, plastic surgery, or changes to color texture and tone of hair, skin, and eyes. The catalog also includes things such as articles of clothing that generate AR media or can change shape or wigs and gear that could be used as a disguise.


!!![[Melee Catalog]]
|!Name |!SC Cost |![Effects(limitations/expansions)] |
|American Knuckles |15 |Concealment II, Harm I |
|Baseball Bat |10 |Harm II |
|Butcher Knife |15 |Harm III |
|Ceramic Knife	|15 |Concealment I, Harm I |
|Katana |20 |Harm IIII |
|Combat Knife |5 |Harm I |
|Machete |15 |Harm III |
|Night Stick |25 |Concealment I, Harm III |
|Quarterstaff |12 |Harm III (restricted I, stretch i) |
|Sledgehammer |22 |Barrier Bypass I, Harm III |
|Spear |12 |Harm III (restricted i, stretch i) |
|Stiletto |17 |Barrier Bypass I, Harm II |
|Stun Rod |28 |Harm II (non-lethal i),  Entrap III |
|Wakizashi |10 |Harm II |
|Weighted Gloves |5 |Harm I |
|Weighted Hammer |22 |Barrier Bypass I, Harm II |


!!![[Gun Catalog]]
|!Name |!SC cost |!Key Effects (to be updated) |
|Hold-out Pistol |27 |Concealment II, Harm II (alter range i, single target, limited uses(8r)) |
|Light Pistol |14 |Harm II (alter range ii, limited uses(12r)) |
|Heavy Pistol |13 |Harm III (alter range ii, single target, limited uses (8r)) |
|Hunting Rifle |19 |Harm III (alter range iii, single target, limited uses (8r)) |
|Combat Rifle |36 |Harm IV (alter range iii, replenish limited uses (16r)) |
|Shotgun |24 |Harm IV (alter range ii, finite uses (4r)) |
|Sawed-off Shotgun |28 |Harm III (alter range ii, finite uses (4r)), Concealment I |
|Long Rifle |32 |Harm IV (alter range iv, single target i, finite uses (8r)) |
|Sub Machine Gun |22 |Harm III (alter range ii, finite uses (16r)) |


!!![[Armor Catalog]]
|!Name |!SC cost |!Effects |
|Heavy coat |7	|Armor I (restricted i), Armor I (restricted i) |
|Leather jacket |10 |Armor II |
|Light undershirt |12 |Harm I, Concealment I |
|Kevlar-lined coat |15 |Armor II, Armor I |
|Concealable vest |15 |Armor II, Armor I |
|Stab vest	|20 |Armor III, Armor I |
|Tactical Vest |20 |Armor II, Armor I, Armor I |
|Special Tactics |24 |Armor III  (restricted i), Armor III  (restricted i), Armor I (restricted i) |
|Combat Armor |31 |Armor IV  (restricted i), Armor III  (restricted i), Armor II  (restricted i) |


!!![[Services Catalog]]
|!Name |!SC cost |!Description |
|''//Net Access //''|<|<|
|General |5 |Allows general access to a Regional Area Network (RAN) or a database, such as a local library. |
|Prime |10 |Allows greater access and unlimited data speeds to a RAN or database. |
|~DayPass |1 |Allows the same access of a general net access contract, but just for 24 hours. |
|~DayPass Prime|2 |Allows the same access of a prime net access contract, but for just 24 hours. |
|''//Vehicles for Hire //''|<|<|
|Otto Cab |0-10 |Automated taxi services that will pick you up and drop you off as ordered, with various additional service packages available. |
|ZiggyRide |1-5 |Small lightweight electric vehicles such as e-bikes or e-scooters that can be used on for short trips for various increments of time.|


!!Utility
!!![[Chems Catalog]]
All chems unless otherwise stated cost 1 street cred. and Preemo versions cost 2 SC. Similarly, all chems last for one hour and are dependent on the use of a vaporizer, or similar gear like below

|!Neb Pump | !4 SC|
|Use item I (single target) |<|
|More accurately described as a vaporizer pump, this small handheld device consists of a chamber that vaporizes chems via  a laser or element, and a pressurized release system that forces the vaporized chems deep into the user's respiratory system.  <br> As a complex action, you can place a single usage of chem into the vaporize and inhale the chem to gain it's effects. The chem is consumed in this process.|<|
