!!![[Digital Catalog]]
Digital gear includes data, accounts, programs, executable or other computer files. This gear is comprised of data that are files and information stored, used, and accessed by terminals and cyber deck. These digital goods take up a resources called memory, the amount of data, which is measured in blocks. The cost of storing the gear in blocks is dependent on the gears [[Street Cred]] cost. Divide the ''SC'' cost of the gear by 10 (minimum of 1) to calculate the number of memory blocks required to store it.

While most digital gear is saved on a cyber terminal or deck, many can be saved to a drive or cassette that can be physically moved in meatspace and slotted into a cyber deck when needed. These cassettes come with their own memory and multiple digital gear can be located on a single cassette that's large enough.

!!!Contracts

The Texas Department of Public Safety issues contracts on wanted criminals throughout the Texaplex. Bounty hunters are licensed private citizens with contracts authorizing them to capture fugitives. Bounties are only paid for the successful capture of live fugitives, and law enforcement stations have ATMs available for the intake of the fugitives and for dispensing the cash reward. Becoming a licensed bounty hunter in the Texaplex has no formal process. Instead you will need a license of being a private investigator or a security or peace officer. One of the greatest difficulties in being a bounty hunter is that contracts are typically only granted for bounties on people with a equal or lower [[SaIN ID|SaIN IDs]]. This leaves the destitute to earn low earnings collecting from the destitute, while the affluent - who don't need the work - can cash in bounties from everyone below them. This leaves contracts providing a low-annual income and keeps bounty hunting as a side gig or for the desperate.

Registration costs an annual fee of 15 SC.






During ''Gear Creation'' [[SC|Street Cred]] is spent on grouping [[Gear Effects]] with associated costs, applying [[Effect Limitations]] or [[Effect Expansions]] to decrease the costs and scope or increase the cost and scope of the effect, respectively.

!![[Effects Terminology]]
Each effect has their own description of how that effect in it's most general form functions. It'll describe what sort of effects or abilities your charter gains while using the gear. some of these can be as simple as a hologram, to shooting a gun, to being able to remotely control multiple helicopters with just your mind and some fancy neural cyberware. 

!!Purchase Effects

!!Select Limitations or Expansion

!!Calculating Cost

!!Example Calculation







Whenever challenges need to be overcome, there is a chance for failure, or your character needs to complete an important plot point, dice are used to determine the result or magnitude of success. If the players want a character to do something, they cannot always simply do it if it could affect the narrative in an import way. The players will have to roll dice, which will say if they fail or succeed (and if so, then by how much) per the rules. From there, the story and narrative develop further.  The probability of success is determined by the skills and abilities of the character, but influenced by the threat or difficulty of the task at hand. There are three (3) general rules.

* [[Using Dice]]
* [[Many Rule Exceptions]]
* [[Always Round Down]]








Goth is a style originating in the post-punk music scene that adopted themes from traditional media, such as print and literature.  The most diverse style, due to its long history, and multigenerational Western influences.  It has many sub-styles that are often formed in niche regional and nightlife scenes. The image of Goth focuses on the artistic self-expression of the self in relation to nihilism and self-alienation due to death and the self-tormenting human condition.

Goths styles often adopt pagan, religious, supernatural or occult and literary images and incorporate them on a personal expression of one’s own style.  Traditional goth styles often adopt or incorporate romantic imagery of death.  However, the watershed markings of Goth style is dark and black clothing, pallid make up, and anachronistic or historically inspired clothing and social graces.  Clothing is typically feminine or androgynous for males and some females, and masculine members will adopt the usage of feminine or unisex make-up and clothing.







<<<
"The magic word isn't "please." It's either "Here's a little something for you" or getting away with it."
<<<

```
//Wheelman, Deliverators, Go-Gos, Bozo or Bosozuka, Bats, Slips, Houdinis, Boosters or Ghosts.
```
Characters belonging to this archetype are experts of getting in, in, around, and away. Grease are the people to go to if you need people or things where they need to be for a job. If you need someone to find the easiest way in, they are your best friend for the best price. Freedom of movement isn’t just what they do, it is their religion.  And this isn’t just about getting into or away from a place through physical or driving skills.  Grease also know how to pay the right people off, or how to abuse or bend the system to fit the needs.

!!!Typical Equipment
*Lock breaker; 
*Vehicle; 
*Stealthy clothing; 
*Concealed weapon; 
*Cloaking; 
*Neural jacks, 
*Mobility gear; 
*Radio scanner; 
*Metro pass; 
*Maps;

!!![[Exploits]]

!!!!The Namesake
Spend 5 style to move through a space typically too small for you without suffering movement penalties or burn because of it.

!!!!Quick Turn
When you attempt a quick or daring maneuver while operating a vehicle, spend 10 style to cover twice the normal distance.

!!!!Trick Jump
Spend 5 style when you attempt a tricky jump, gymnastic stunt, or feat of parkour, and roll with strong edge.

!!!!Live Wire
Spend 5 style to get strong edge when attempting to hot-wire a vehicle.

!!!!There’s Always A Guy
Spend 10 style and an appropriate amount of credits to gain access to a space or to get access to an item or unusual request through the use of the other person.

!!!!Additional Contact
You have access to an additional contact with a loyalty and connection of 5 and access to a specialized ability or resource.

!!!!The Belonging Kind
You have ready access to gear comparable to your common gear but in a second style. You are able to adopt this second style's speak and habits and pass as any other person with this style.







Houston is the largest city by land and population and houses many refuges that come from the Gulf coast. It's named after the first and third president of the Republic of Texas, Sam Houston. Together with its satellite cities, The Greater Houston Metropolitan area, or ''Greater Houston'' is still only second to the Population to DFW and is the largest economic and Asian cultural center of the Texaplex. Encompassing the Galveston Bay area, Greater Houston is a transportation and infrastructural hub for virtually all shipping exports and imports that reaches out into the Gulf of Mexico. 

The amount of Concrete and asphalt which composes the infrastructure of Houston has made Houston susceptible to both flash floods and raising sea waters. This is only compounded by Climate Change and global warming. 

Unfortunately, the decline of petrochemicals and oil production has left many of the manufacturing centers nascent, with many plants having to switch to other chemical processing. This has not stopped a rich medical research and biological agent industry to grow based on the research being conducted on the polluted waterways and bay. The greater Houston area is also home to the most foreign and corporate consulates in the Texaplex and the remaining United States.








!!''__Hold-out Pistol__''
!!!!Concealment II, Harm II (alter range i, single target, limited uses(8r)) – 27 SC
Hold out pistols fill a niche market for person looking to have compact, light firearms that sacrifice power and range for maneuverability, concealment, and reliability. Their short barrels and specially designed hammers and firing mechanisms allow them to be carried in small bags and clothes pockets without snagging or showing a distinct profile. When rolling to detect this weapon via a pat down or sight, the searcher suffers 2 [[Burn]]. When rolling to attack a target within ''short range'' when using this weapon, every success deals 5 ''ballistic'' damage. A hold-out pistol has ''8 uses'' before it needs to be replenished prior to any additional uses. It takes pistol ammunition to replenish the uses.

!!__''Light Pistol''__
!!!!Harm II (alter range ii, limited uses(12r)) – 14 SC
A light pistol is the archetypical personal defense weapon for the law abiding citizen. It is light, readily manufactured, and uses common ammo. It’s common presence on the street allows for criminal and cops to 
wander the streets inconspicuously among the average citizenry. When rolling to attack a valid target within ''medium range'' while using this weapon, you deal 5 ''ballistic ''damage per success. This weapon has ''12 uses'' which must be replenished prior to any additional uses. Pistol ammo is required for each additional use.

!!__''Heavy Pistol''__
!!!!Harm III (alter range ii, single target, limited uses (8r)) – 13 SC
A category of hand-guns known for chambering large rounds, the heavy pistol is the largest a pistol can be and still be a pistol. These hand cannon rose in popularity due to their presence in the action and hero films of 1980s and 1990s American cinema, and they’re popular with any punk on the street and cop on the beat. Today, a heavy pistol might be a revolver or magazine fed , but either way its appearance is intimidating and distinct. When rolling to attack a valid target within ''medium range'', you deal ''7 ballistic damage'' per success. A heavy pistol has ''8 uses'', before it needs to be replenish with pistol rounds for additional uses. 

!!__''Hunting Rifle ''__
!!!!Harm III (alter range iii, single target, limited uses (8r)) – 19 SC
A hunting rifle is any lightweight semi-automatic rifle that fires intermediate powered ammunition intended for hunting. A hunting rifle was the typical introduction to firearms in Texas prior to the turn of the millennium. Today, very few hunting rifles are manufactured due to the decline of hunting grounds and the expensiveness of the tickets and licensing. When rolling to attack a ''single target'' within ''long range'', you deal ''7 ballistic damage'' per success. You can only target one valid target per dice roll. This weapon has ''8  uses'' that can be replenished for additional uses. It takes rifle ammunition to replenish the uses.

!!__''Combat Rifle''__
!!!!Harm IV (alter range iii, replenish limited uses (16r)) – 36 SC
A combat rifle is any rifle capable of automatic fire, individually portable and uses a detachable cartridge to load ammunition. Often sometimes conflated with assault rifle, a combat rifle lacks their semi-automatic or burst fire capabilities. Combat rifles are commonly used by western states and countries as a form of militia or martial defense, but are mostly produce by the eastern states of Honk Kong Free State, Nippon, and China. When you roll to attack a target within long range using this weapon, you deal 9 damage per success. This weapon has 16 uses, before it has to be replenished with Rifle ammo prior to additional uses.

!!__''Shotgun''__
!!!!Harm IV (alter range ii, finite uses (4r)) – 24 SC
A short length shoulder fired weapon designed to shoot shot. The large number of projectiles makes the shotgun a useful mobile and close quarter weapon. Shotguns have a place both in sports such as hunting and skeet, but today they are used to hunt a more dangerous game due to the decline of natural fauna. Today, the shotgun sees a significant usage by military, law enforcement and criminal organizations alike. When you roll to attack a target within ''medium range'', you deal ''9 puncture damage'' per success. This weapon has ''4 uses'' before it no longer continues to function. The weapon can be reloaded using shotgun shells, at which point it regains it’s number of uses.

!!__''Sawed-off Shotgun''__
!!!!Harm III (alter range ii, finite uses (4r)), Concealment I – 28 SC
An illegal and quickly produced version that rose to infamy during the decade prior to the Civil Rights Movement, the sawed-off shotgun is the archetypical banned weapon in American history. Following the Freedom Amendments, the sawed-off shotgun rose quickly as a deadly, close range weapon for both domestic defense and criminal enterprises alike. When you attack a target within ''short range'', you deal ''7 puncture damage'' per success. When hidden underneath clothing, rolls to detect the weapon via sight suffers 1 [[Burn]]. The shotgun has ''4 uses'' before it can no longer be used. It must be reloaded with shotgun shells prior to be using again.

!!__''Long Rifle''__
!!!!Harm IV (alter range iv, single target i, finite uses (8r)) – 32 SC
This weapon is only intended for use in hunting game by those who enjoy to shoot through their targets and from very far distances. A long rifle is any rifle that is a firearm fire rifle cartridge rounds and is non-automatic. Often these weapons are bolt action and require time to aim via scopes. When rolling to attack a single target within ''extended-short'' range, you deal ''9 ballistic damage'' for every success. You are only able to target one target per dice roll when attacking with this weapon.

!!__''Submachine Gun''__
!!!!Harm III (alter range ii, finite uses (16r)) – 22 SC
Originated from the World War Era, these century old weapons still remain used today, albeit on a different battlefield. Submachine guns are portable magazine feed firearms known for sustainable firing of pistol rounds. Their molecularity and iconic image helped define and facilitate mafia and criminal activity it’s in the 1960s. Today they are used by tactical police due to their ability to not over penetrate, and the cheapness of their ammunition.
When attacking a target within medium range while using a submachine gun, you deal ''5 ballistic damage'' per success. A submachine gun has ''16 uses'' before it needs to be reloaded with  pistol rounds prior to additional uses. 







Guzzlers is a style adopted by the necessity of the lowest social economic classes. They recreate and reconstruct items, gear, and lives out of found materials and gear.  Their namesake is derived from the eponymous derogatory term for the sound that their ethanol fueled combustion engine rigs and bikes make.  They often drive these vehicles through the dilapidated and old city portions of [[The Texaplex]] susceptible to [[The Dust]].

Guzzler gear and clothing reinforce traditional familial deference of small clans and identity cults often perceived as criminal or delinquent in nature or origin. Additionally, their equipage is unique in that they were never manufactured but created from the materials of the streets. Guzzlers often fosters a rebellion of any pre-made good, and usage of clothing to form a group identity with their family. Guzzlers of the same group will often dress in similar patterns, iconography, or colors to signify their familial allegiances and will speak in broken slang with specific connotations.







''Hearty'' is a measure of a character’s passive physical will and fortitude.  Its typically used for actions that requires resisting physical forces or enduring harmful effects.  Example actions include remaining awake for extended periods of time, resisting the effects of poison, overcoming toxins or addiction, and other harmful effects. Characters with grit and survivors both have high Hearty scores.






When capitalized, ''Hits'' refers to the game term and mechanic for [[Determining Success]]. When not capitalized, it refers to typical meaning of the word based on the syntax. such as hitting the roof, hitting the hay or getting hit.






Horses have always been a symbol of the Wild West and [[Texas]]. Today is no different. Even today, cars and bikes are often named after horses or famous horses. In the Texaplex, Lonestar Park in [[DFW|Dallas-Fort Worth]] and Manor Downs in [[Austin|Austin-San Antonio]] serve as the premier hippodromes and event spaces for the sport of horse races and rodeo. There, cybernetically enhanced stallions compete for an ever growing cash prize where sponsors pay horse owners through even greater performance enhancements.

There still exists a market for non-enhanced horse races, but most are done by stodgy types who do so for re-enactments of the past of the sport and to flaunt their wealth. Such clubs are exclusive, and hard to find and have hard security to keep out undesirable from their million-dollar animals. Such animals are expensive due to the damage the dust has caused to the animals’ plains as well as to the genetics of the animals themselves.







Each player rolls for initiative when told to do so by the GM. Everyone rolls either Cool or Perception depending on whether the character is surprised, simply unaware, or readied for action, respectively. Each person records the number of hits.  Turns are then ordered based on the number of successes in descending order.  If there should be a tie, the player with the greater valued ability rolled goes before.

After initiative is rolled, the GM notes which initiatives rolled were for the PCs and which were for NPCs. Those rolled for PCs are for the PCS, while those rolled by NPCS are for the NPCs. 

Beginning at the top of the initiative order each round, the players and GM determine which characters act. PCs and NPCs can only act on their respective turns. Characters can only take 1 turn per round. However, If a character rolls 5 or more [[Hits]] on their initiative, they get to act twice. Once in a normal character initiative turn and once at the end of the round. But if a character rolls 7 or more Hits, they instead act once in a normal character initiative order and once at the beginning of the initiative order. The very last thing that occurs are continuing effects and the environment, which are done after all the characters have taken their turns.







Your player character is a cyberpunk character, using technology to fight against your oppression. You might also take the fight to other people's oppression, but others would just say that that's part of your style. There's no way save everyone. But what makes your character special is that they are a ''Jobber.'' You complete jobs semi-anonymously on behalf of [[ShadowBizs]], [[Megacorporations]],  or whoever can afford your skills.

Jobber are so named because they "do their job." They aren't there to win, but to get the job done for the benefit of those that hire them. What a jobber does with the [[Nova Kredits]] is up to them. But most spend that money and [[Street Cred]] on investments, maintaining [[Spending Street Cred##Contacts]], acquiring new [[Gear|Gear Catalog]], and implanting themselves with cyberware to push themselves to the limit.

!!Origins
While [[Megacorporations]] 


!!Jobber's Code
More of a series of guidelines than a strict code, the ''Jobber's Code'' is social contract between jobber's that may be hired against each other. Simply stated, it's "Don't get in the way of another jobber, unless they'd get in your way. Don't kill, maim a fellow jobber." Jobbers that kill other jobbers are called ''headhunters,'' and become black listed by most fixers.

!!Jobs
Jobbers can get paid for many different sorts of jobs. Most of it requires at least one illegal act. That's why a jobber is hired by an anonymous Mr. Johnson and comes with the boiler plate agreement that your actions will be denied.

|!Type |!Description |
|''Demolition ''|The jobbers are hired to destroy a target, typically some capital or data asset|
|''Wet Work'' |Jobs that involve killing people. Killing may not be the primary objective, but some Mr. Johnson may request not wet work, penalizing the pay for a job if someone if killed during it. |
|''Extraction ''|The jobbers are higher to remove a target from a secured location. This work often involves stealth, but if wet work is on the table a more direct and violent approach is followed. |
|''Mayhem ''|The Jobbers are hired to ransack and damage a target location. This work is often done for intimidation or as a distraction for another team pulling a job. |
|''Insertion ''|The Jobbers are hired to place bugs, viruses, or people in certain locations undetected. Many corporations use jobbers for insertions to test their own security. |
|''Delivery ''|The jobbers hired the team to protect and deliver a package to a secondary location within a time limit. |
|''Investigate ''|The jobbers are hired to locate and case a package or locate need to know information. This job is best suited for a mixed team of specialists who can handle whatever the streets throw at them. |
|''Security'' |The jobbers are hired to protect a package and or location from intrusive forces. This operations are typically against an opposing team of jobbers and rivals. |


!!Fixers
A ''Fixer'' is an individual that connects Jobs with Jobs. They have a large number of contacts that allows them to locate and organize teams of jobbers for anonymous employers referred to as Mr. Johnsons. Most Mr. Johnsons, regardless of their own employers, will first contact a known fixer to locate prospective jobbers for job. 

Fixers know many secrets, including the public identities of Mr. Johnsons, jobber, and such. Fixers are therefore some of the most professional of jobbers, as they will not easily part with this information, as discretion and reputation protection can be the largest part of their services they render.

!!Contracting
Amid a rising crime rate, the Texaplex has set up a legalized contract cystem, in which registered bounty hunters chase criminals and bring them back alive for a reward. Registered bounty hunters can make some money, but since all contracts are entered and fulfilled on delivery of the live bounty, the field can be quite competitive for larger bounties. It isn't too uncommon for bounties to escape or exchange hands before the bounty is eventually turned over for payment. This leaves many bounty hunters with low-annual incomes, sometimes just enough to survive.

















"""
''chrome''
/krōm/
//noun//
"""

*chromium plate as a decorative or protective finish on motor-vehichles fittings and other products
**denoting dompounds of alloys of chromium
**//informal// - short for chrome yellow, a pigment
*//informal// - cybernetic implants and prostesis

//verb//

*//informal// - to augment or customize something through the installation of non-manufacturer components

"""
''-drome''
/drəʊm/
//suffix//
"""

*denoting a place for running or racing
*denoting something that runs or moves in a certain way






''Luck'' is a measure of the benefit of factors not know to others, either through an indeterminable favorableness or unexplained coincidence.  When no other attribute of a character explains why things occur in overly complex systems, it can only be attributed to a character’s luck.  Example events include knocking on the correct door, recklessly taking action with no thought, guessing the correct passcode, and resources being available that are needed. Characters that seem to always be in the right place at the right time have high Luck scores. So do those that seem to benefit from no action of their own or those around them.






The basic rules are quite simple because they are intended to do so much.  However, there will be multiple times during play that a specific rule says to do or not do something which contradicts another rule.  Sometimes their may be two rules that interact in interesting ways.  There are two ways to resolve these issues.

The rule that is more specific or handles a more unique action takes precedence, and the [[GM|Being a Game Master]] decides which rule takes precedence. The ability of a GM to determine how to rules come in effect is why it is important to have your GM be a person that everyone can trust.







Despite the name, meat parlors are more than a butcher shop. There are multiple names for meat parlors: Bunraku parlors, Doll houses, Puppet shows, Marionette clubs, Bunny ranches. Some say that they are one of the worst things ever to exist, but there also so good that they're almost legal. At its best, desperate people needing money or to get out of a fire use illegal and kraked SimStims called ~BlkStims to block out their senses and memory and rent their body out to clients, becoming a doll. After working a few hours, the desperate doll has their senses and control of their body back with a lots of credits but no memory of what happened while under. 

There is a lot that can go wrong or be worse. Sometimes the person isn’t willing, but forced into it. There are enough humans trafficked to match the demand in any one region of the Texaplex. Sometimes the doll, bunny, or Marion remembers what happened. Some clients aren’t gentle or want illegal acts. Most of the time, the bunnies don’t want to remember and are more than pleased to have the experiences just be faint pops of light at the edge of their consciousness. Sometimes the entire Doll’s personality and memories are deleted from the brain and a new desired one is slotted in to replace it permanently. And sometimes, extreme, and harsh physical and cosmetic surgery is used to make the doll look like the persona slotted into them.

With all that being said about this shadowbiz, there is nothing like the money to be made by a doll if they work at one of the better known parlors or for more reputable clients. the money can be enough to for the doll to escape their current life or acquire expensive top of the line cyberware or medication. Unfortunately, that’s not the case for all of them. Some parlors function as illicit adult dance clubs, but most are sex workers when they slot out and become a bunraku.







''Megacity One'' is the largest urban area in the Americas, and grew out of New York City. It serves as the northwestern anchor of the Atlantic Sprawl and almost seamlessly connects with the city of Boston to it's northeast and the city of Philadelphia to it's southwest. It also is also in the in the vicinity of the [[Great Lakes City]], anchored by the cities of Chicago, Detroit, Toronto and Montreal. Any and all things for sail can be found in Megacity One. Those that can't can be found in Chiba City on Tokyo Bay.






Megacorps, or ''Megacorporations,'' are large multinational umbrella corporations, typically private conglomerates, that control vast numbers of smaller subsidiaries that manufacture and produce anything for basic good to specialized technology. If a company produces revenue from bread, bullets, and barbiturates, it's most likely a megacorp. 

Megacorps do not necessarily need to be a monopoly. They just need to place their own survival and growth as it's key objective and have transnational power or the power to act in accordance to their own rules. They use their resources to protect themselves and their property from outside forces and goals to expand across all markets. This often involves having national and state laws re-written or enforce for their benefit or acting as independent jurisdictions of their own. They achieve these goals through the leveraging of capital and monetary/economic resources, i.e. bribes.

[[Jobbers|Jobber]] are often hired as unethical  means of competing against other megacorporations and market threats when politics aren't viable of there is a short time table. With the effective absolution of the corporate steward and moral boundaries in the 1970s, megacorps became an inevitable politico-economic force.

!![[The Big 12]]
Out of all the megacorporations there are 12 corporations with such a large political and market share in [[The Texaplex]] that their immediate dissolution could create an economic crisis. These corporations, in no particular order are:

* [[Sinotech Group]]
* [[The Dallas Corporation]]
* [[Boeing-Reeves Corporation]]
* [[Mitsubishi Group]]
* [[Texas Instruments]]
* [[Gaius-Masuda Corporation]]
* [[The Lesan Group]]
* [[Teletronics International]]
* [[Philo Corporation]]
* [[Sighard Inc.]]
* [[Morgan, Chase & Stanley]]
* [[Rotwang Industries]]








!!__''American Knuckles''__
!!!!Harm I, Concealment I – 15 SC
This small metal weapon enhances your punches and strikes by concentrating the force of your punches onto small points on your fist and distributes the reactionary force through your palm and arm.  When attacking, the american knuckles deal 3 crushing damage per success.  Being small and easy to hide in one’s pockets, when the american knuckles are being searched for on you, the searcher suffers 1 burn when doing so.

!!__''Baseball Bat''__
!!!!Harm II – 10 SC
Originally designed for playing baseball, these small wooden or metal pieces of sports equipment are effect bludgeoning weapons when you need one. And for extra benefit, the sports grip gives you a nice hand fell when you give it a good squeeze. When you attack, you deal 5 crushing damage per success on the attack.

!!__''Butcher’s Cleaver ''__
!!!!Harm III – 15 SC
This cleaver is a rectangular-bladed knife with an especially tough edge meant to withstand repeated blows and used for the disassembling of carcasses.  Its swing relies on sheer momentum to cut efficiently and is swung like a hatchet. When attacking, the butcher's cleaver deals 7 cutting damage per success.

!!__''Ceramic Knife''__
!!!!Concealment I, Harm I – 12 SC
A small fixed blade tool less than 5 inches in length made of a durable ceramic material, a ceramic knife's small size and availability at any mega-store makes is inconspicuous, but it’s material make’s it difficult to detect in metal detectors. When attacking, the ceramic knife deals 3 cutting damage per success. When someone attempts to locate the knife through security message such as metal detection, they suffer 1 burn when rolling as the metal pin in the handle has been removed.

!!__''Combat Knife''__
!!!!Harm I – 5 SC
A small knife designed for fighting hand-to-hand, a combat is  typically for military use. The original combat knives were originally used during trench warfare of the first World War.  Attacks made with this weapon deal 3 cutting damage per success.

!!__''Katana''__
!!!!Harm IV – 20 SC
A traditional longsword with a single-edged curved blade, A katana's grip is long enough to accommodate two hands and but can be used singled handed.  While the origin of the katana was from a long tedious process, today, most katanas are made in a industrial matter except for those made specifically in [[Nippon]]. When attacking, the katana deals 9 cutting damage per success.

!!__''Machete''__
!!!!Harm III – 15 SC
This broad blade is often used as both an axe for utility and a short sword during martial combat. Today, it’s often seen in tropical climates due to its ability to cut through undergrowth and its cultural superfluousness.  Attacks made with this weapon deal 7 cutting damage per success.

!!__''Nightstick''__
!!!!Concealment I, Harm III – 25 SC
This cylindrical is based on the truncheon that is typically used by law enforcement. However, it’s added mass and increased length gives it greater power behind each of it’s hits compared to it’s legal counterparts.  When attacking using the nightstick, it deals 7 crushing damage per success. Being a sleek silhouette

!!__''Quarterstaff''__
Harm III (restricted I, stretch i) – 12 SC
A long wooden staff often capped on both ends by metal tips, spikes or ferrules. Measuring at least 6 feet but up to roughly 9 feet in length, the quarter staff can deliver lethal force over a great distance. When attacking a target within immediate range of a point within immediate range, you deal 7 crushing damage.  When in a corridor or a residential hallway, suffer 1 burn on all attacks with this weapon.

!!__''Sledgehammer''__
!!!!Barrier Bypass I, Harm III – 22 SC
A two-handed tool typically used during construction work, and driving posts and nails, a sledgehammer's metal heads and flat hammer faces allows it to deliver massive forces, not just to structures but also to a combatant’s bones, sternum or skull. When attacking using the sledge hammer, you deal 7 crushing damage and ignore 1 burn from armor against crushing attacks.

!!__''Spear''__
!!!!Harm III (restricted I, stretch i)  – 12 SC
Long lived weapon dating to the stone age, a spear is a polearm headed by a pointed or sharp implement. When attacking a target within immediate range of a point within immediate range, you deal 7 puncturing damage.  When in a corridor or a hallway, suffer 1 burn on all attacks with this weapon. Modern spears are typically illegal for all other purposes besides fishing and game hunting.

!!__''Stiletto''__
!!!!Barrier Bypass I, Harm II  – 17 SC
A long thing needle weapon designed to pierce and pierce only.  Unlike other dagger like weapons, a stiletto does not have a cutting edge but instead uses it’s narrow shape to pass through flesh and bypass bone. When attacking with this weapon, you deal 5 puncturing damage and ignore 1 burn from armor against puncturing armor.

!!__''Stun Rod''__
!!!!Harm (non-lethal I) II, Entrap III – 28 SC
A common self-defense weapon easily carried in a purse or jacket pocket, a stun rod is any prostitutes preferred weapon. It electrocutes an attacker upon contact with its prod shaped end, causing the attacker some pain, but disabling the attacker for enough time to escape. When attacking a target within immediate range with a stun rod, you deal 5 non-lethal electro damage per success and the target is now entrapped. The entrap effect lasts for 1 minute or until the target gets 3 successes on a Hearty roll. While under this affect, a character drops prone and convulses on the ground.

!!__''Wakizashi''__
!!!!Harm II – 10 SC
One of the two swords worn by samurai in feudal Nippon, the wakazashi, like the katana, saw adoption in western society due to its involvement with seppuku. Often a companion sword to the katana, the wakazashi has seen its uses separate from it, particularly those that focus on ritual and death. When attacking a target within immediate range with the wakazashi, you deal 5 slashing damage per success.

!!__''Weighted Gloves''__
!!!!Harm I,Barrier I, x2 Armor I – 22 SC
These gloves, while a weapon, are designed to protect their wearer in hand-to-hand and close combat. They are made of cut and punture resistant material and the back of each hand is filled with powdered metal or polymers. When attacking a target within immediate range you deal 3 crushing damage per success. While using these gloves, all cutting and crushing damage is reduced by 2 per success and all rolls to deal cutting damage suffer 1 burn against you.

!!__''Weighted Hammer''__
!!!!Barrier Bypass I, Harm II – 22 SC
This convenient hardware and athletic item is sometimes used by gangers or kept in the back of a car for the occasional road rage incident. This has a roughened flat or ball-peen head covered in metal to help punch through metal and thin platting. The head is often filled with lead or sand to give it enough mass to deal some damage and break bones. When rolling to attack using this weapon you ignore 1 burn from armor against crushing damage and deal 5 crushing damage per success.









At this point, you should have a good idea of what your character is like and what they can do.  You should have some understanding at what they are the worst at and what they are the best at.  Maybe you have figured out the key aspects of your characters personality.  Keep these in mind when you decide upon your character’s name.

Your name is more than what you are called.  On the streets, a name not only identifies you, but also your backstory, your abilities, and your characters personality or style.  It’s your brand and your livelihood.  Stories don’t sound as serious or tense if you had to fight past Daisy the bouncer, instead of Crack-Jaw.  The cool samurai should sound like a cool samurai. The super starlet should sound chic and provocative, and not like an old lady. Names should not sound mundane either. Your character is the main character of a cool story, so keep Sean and Jessica off the short list for your runner’s names.

Names can come from a multitude of places as well.  There is a soft rule to follow, nobody can give themselves their own nick name.  It never turns out so well, and people never take those names seriously.   Names must be earned.  People might not take you seriously until you prove that you deserve the name, especially flashy ones.  Your name may have been given to you by someone else, possibly a friend, a fixer, a person you ran a job with, or a rival.

Finally, make sure your name is appropriate for the story everyone else at the table wants to play.  ~HaxAtacc won’t fit in so well with Booter, and Sweet Pickles.  Similarly, Mandrake works well with Cobra and Poison Lilly, but no so well with Z3r0 and Craps.  Be conscious with your name, but always choose a name that you like for your character.  They are your character.

If you need a seed to come up with your own name or want to choose from a pre-existing set of examples, see [[This list of names|C: Runner Names]] for runners.







''~NearMe'' is a short-wave and wireless means of net enabled devices to communication with ~NearMe enabled Net Nodes and terminals. Most [[AR|The Many Worlds]] is transferred via ~NearMe, and serves as a convenient means of generating holograms for those with the tech to see them.






|!Net Jammer | !16 SC|
|Barrier I (area of effect i) |<|
|A net jammer is a small portable device that disrupts the Near Me band of communication in a sphere with a radius of 1 meter, centered on the net jammer. The disruption continues until the device is turned off. Any person attempting a net action that passes through or in the the jammer's area of effect suffers 1 burn.|<|

|!Proximity Alert | !19 SC|
|Detect I (increase area iii), Has AI I, Communication I (alter range iii) |<|
|A proximity alert detects movement in a 5 meter cone originating from itself. Should it detect movement, it will send an alert to it's registered users' PAN via a net node within medium range.|<|

Acetura 9
Jack, Memory -- 6 SC

Samsung XS
Jack, Barrier I, Memory III -- 18 SC

Pembrose Executive 
Jack, Communication II, Barrier III, Memory IX -- 50 SC


!!Cyberdecks

Journer 1
Jack, Use item I x2, Has Memory I, Generate Media x2, Movement via Medium -- 34 SC


Nokita RVX-7
Jack, Use Item I x3, Memory IV, Generate Media, Movement via Medium II, Barrier -- 51 SC






The ''Nova Kredit'', symbol ₦, is the de facto global currency and is controlled by the [[Aeschbacher-Mitsui Orbital Bank]]. While originally designed as a digital reserve currency, it replaced nearly every currency that experienced hyperinflation during the [[Global Depression]]. It also serves as the official currency of the [[Free California]], United Republics of Sudan, [[Nippon]], [[The Free Society]], and is accepted nearly universally in the Texaplex outside of [[Fedland]].

No physical form of coinage exists, but the digital currency can be transferred physically through the means of [[KlikStiks]].








[[Perception]] is a measure of a character’s spacial awareness, use of physical senses, and their keen ability to notice small details. The more perceptive a character is the better able they are to notice hidden weapons or traps, locate threats, or search an area. Investigators and spies both have high Perception scores.






[[Block Generation|F: Block Generation]]: Step 4

Next the table will use proper nouns spoken in Step 2: [[Say Proper Nouns]] by attaching them to types of places or people (faces) by name. . Some people find it easier to think of a place and figure out who belongs there, and some people have an easier time the other way around. The people and places each player develops should be important to the locale and the Player Characters. 

!!PLACES
''Places'' are common area or places of note that the ''PCs'' and other characters are drawn to. Turns should go around the table, such that each player is able to develop a place tied to their PC and the other characters. Whatever the place is, it should hold some significance and serve as an anchor point for role play and game events. a place could be a noodle shop run by a street contact, a front for a [[ShadowBiz|ShadowBizs]] your character is in, or even a safe haven run by a modest benefactor. In our example, the place is a noodle shop is just a noddle shop call Sour Noodle that all the players go to, like a restaurant or bar from an American sitcom.

Places should be defined by the ''faces'' there, a ''common event'', and a ''front''. The faces we will talk about in just a little bit. The common event is something familiar and easily attached to the place. In the Sour Noodle example, the common event could be the dinner specials, or the dominoes games in the back room. The front is a description of a places key key defining features, like the the jukebox that only plays the same three songs no mater what, the broken neon signage, the oily smells and the 

!!FACES
Faces are the NPCs that the main characters meet. They are typically non-combatants but are more social focused people that assist the story on a narrative or character level. The faces are tied to characters or the places they find. The face Brigade at Sour Noodles could be a contact there or a recognizable element that the players know they can go to for some narrative development. If you’ve ever been a regular at a place and one day your favorite worker or another regular is no longer around, then you might be familiar to that feeling of being shocked and sad. A face should leave your character with a similar feeling.

Faces are defined by their ''name'', a ''style distinction'', a ''motivation'', and at least two ''traits''. The style distinction is the character's style and a physical characteristic that a person could be described by. Examples include an eye patch, a Candian Tuxedo, a loud and twitchy cybernetic arm, a [[Guzzler|Guzzlers]] back patch. The motivation of a face is what they stand for and the primary characteristic that influences what and how they react to the actions of the PCs and the world. A trait tells something fun and interesting about the character. They should be short descriptions that are specific to the face and make them stand out more. Phrases like, “they have nimble fingers” are okay, but phrases like “ they’ve picked all the locks on 7th Avenue” is something more specific.

```
NOTE TO THE GM
Once every player has created at least one place and one face, it's time to move onto the next step. While some players are more upfront and some are more reserved, it's important to ensure that not just one player develops the places and faces. Once one player exerts too much control on the narrative, it loses it's edge and its ability to excite.
```









When all the [[non-GM players|The Other Players]] have characters, play usually begins.  The [[GM|Being a Game Master]] provides an opening narrative and description, and the other players begin deciding what their player would do. Then the GM decides what the effect of all the PCs’ actions are with the aid of the dice.  The true personality of a roleplaying game is taking a role in the story and acting in a manner befit of all the characters and plot.  Don’t worry about having to be an actor.  You might use accents or unusual voices for your characters, or maybe you might narrate all actions in third-person.  Do whatever is more fun for the table of players and gets everyone into the game.

"""
Play usually occurs according to this basic pattern:
''GM narrates the environment.'' The GM tells the players where the PC are and describe things and other characters that the PC can interact with.
''The other players describe what the PCs are doing.''  The players must decide what actions if any their PC does.  Such as ‘I pick up the case’, ‘I run down the hall’, ‘I shoot the guard’, ‘I tell a lie’, and so on.  These actions then need to be resolved with an appropriate effect.  Sometimes these actions have a chance for success and failure, which is when the dice need to be used.
''GM narrates the effects of the other players’ actions.''  They determine the results of the PC actions and the terms of success for a dice roll.  They also determine how the Non-Player Characters (NPCs) and environment evolves and reacts to any actions taken.
"""

This pattern continues until the game ends for the day, and starts again the next time everyone plays,







''Punkeis'' is a style that originates as a street wear inspired by the punk scenes of the 1970s and 1980s that was further developed in Tokyo and then came back to the former United States. The style is noted for its themes of retaliation against the alienating effects of popular culture and Corpo fashion scene. It reinforces self-expression, independence and self-reliance.

Clothing and gear focus on deconstruction and reconstructing things in unconventional means. A Punkei’s clothing are made of discarded and second-hand goods from 20 years ago.  Typical social themes emphasize fighting the status quo, reinforcing the pride in the working or blue-collar class, and establishing anarchy as the means of self-governance. Their music is loud, abrasive, angry and young.







<<<
"Whatever you do, don't look her in the frak'n eyes. She might think you are challenging her or are interested. Either way, you may end up with scars."
<<<

```
//Ip-Lees, Fatale, Slasher, Ripper, Psycho, Swift, Shade, Bride, Snake, Lucy, Blade, Knives//
```

Characters belonging to this archetype are the quick killers that prefer to get in their targets personal space and get their own hands dirty, literally.  They use small concealed weapons, toxins, poisons, and hands to get the job done. They use wits, agility, and sometimes sexuality when their cybered-out reflexes and optics aren’t enough to get paid. Where ever they go and whatever they go by, they kill, and they kill fast.

!!![[Abilities]] and [[Foci]]
Choose one ability array from below:

| 4 | !Charm | 5 |

!!!Typical Equipment
*Light blad
*Light gun
*Concealed weapon
*Visual gear
*Pheromones
*Poisons
*Toxins
*Movement enhacing cyberware
*Optics,

[[Exploits]]

!!!!Additional Cyberware
Your maximum renegade score and renegade score for are both increased by 15.

!!!!Occipital Optics
You ignore up to 1 burn when detecting threats which you cannot see or are unaware of. 

!!!!Resourceful Market
Choose from one of the following: poisons, drugs, narcoalgorithms, concealed weapons. You have to pay roughly 1/5th less of the usual price for acquiring items of that type.

!!!!Palmed Poison
You can conceal a small item on your person and have edge on keeping it hidden.

!!!!Favored Enemy
You can spend 5 style to grant edge on all attacks for the round against targets belonging to a general type determined when you choose this skill.

!!!!From Above
You have string edge on all attacks against targets that are not aware of you attacking them.

!!!!The Second Tap
Spend 10 style whenever you attack a target that attacked you this round. You have edge on all attacks against them this round.







[[Block Generation|F: Block Generation]]: Step 6

```
NOTE TO THE GM
This final step may want to not be performed in front of the other players for games that focus on espionage or mystery, or because the game isn't ready for a central tension and everyone is still getting used to play CHROMODROME.  You might also ant to skip this step entirely. That's fine block generation is completely optional.

```


The sixth step is all about the previous steps and forming the most immediate threat to the block and the player characters. The threat is going to be some face or organization that is imposing themselves on the blocks’ people, resources, or way of life. Other threats exist as well. What happens when the block is sold to a corporation that wants to rebuild the block, and is looking to kick out the tenants? What happens when a new strange drug begins being sold on the streets? 

Maybe it’s a power vacuum. What happens when the block president vanished? What happens to the block when the corporation it’s tenants worked for declared bankruptcy. It could also be a threat to the play character’s power. What happens when a character’s street cred is on the line? What happens when there’s a turf war?

As you can see, a question is a good starting point for beginning the threat. A question gets your mind racing and picking up or inventing connections you didn’t realize before. After you have that idea, attach the created faces, places, and bizses to see how the players handle it and if the player characters come out better for it, if they even come out of it at all. You may find this step naturally reoccurring during play as threats are dealt with and new threats appear and old one's reappear.







A character's ''Renegade Score'' represent's their unpredictable and how difficult they are in being controlled by Megacorporations and others. As cyberware is installed into a person and they become addicted to drugs, a character reduces their current renegade score. This represent's their susceptibility to being forced to conform to another's will, and their ability to be controlled by the system in.

!!Renegade Score Zero
When a Renegade Score is reduced to zero a character loses the spirit that wills them to be an outlier, a punk, or renegade. At Renegade score zero or less, a character loses that human spirit of revolution and grand unpredictability. If a main character has a Renegade score of zero or less, they become a Non-player character by the end of the session. At which point the GM controls them for the remainder of the narrative. Unfortunately, a lose of renegade spirit is irreversible, Even if the Cyberware is removed , a cost is still paid for having it installed. This reduction even lasts after a drug addiction is overcome.







''Rigs'' are semi-automated systems capable of movement without the direct control of an individual. They can be programmed to follow pre-determined paths or carry out simple instructions. Rigs were originally designed for military, then policing and scientific purposes. Through the use of surplus stores and direct retail outlets, they eventually made their way onto the streets. Today, rigs can be used by anyone , and the maturing miniaturization of the requisite technologies has developed some rigs that can be stored in a space no larger than suitcase.

Each rig comes with it's own means of controlling it. The Bull, Dog, and Hawk all follow instructions from a registered PAN, meanwhile the Skeeter and the Spider both can be puppeted through the use of included heads-up displays and interfacing.

!!__Bull__
!!!!Has AI II, Has Hardpoints I, Communication II(increase ii), Has Speed I, Has Memory I, Has Sense I -- 32 SC

''Bulls'' are common rigs used for the movement of heavy cargo and materials in warehouses and in docks. Capable of movement along a path designated by you, these large rigs can move terrestrially at a speed half of that of a natural human. They are only capable of 2 commands at a time, and are commonly instructed to follow you at a set distance or to go to two successive points. A bull's  hardpoints allow them to be fitted with a single piece of gear, such as a shield platform or, the favorite of gangers, a mounted gun. 

You are able to issue commands up to long range via a registered comm. The bull is able to record 30 minutes of black and white video, a hold over for insurance policies.

!!__Dog__
!!!!Has AI III, Communication I(increase iIi), Has Speed III, Enhanced Sense II, Harm III, Has Ability V, Has Foci II --  117 SC	

A ''Dog'' is a nearly fully autonomous rig first adopted for use in the military as an auxiliary to K-9 units during the Proxy Wars in the Middle East. Some talented technicians either recreated or smuggled decommissioned dog units that they became attached to stateside. A Dog is capable of following moderately complex commands roughly below the abilities of natural dogs, but are still able to access the best means of completing the command and acting almost independently.

A dog is capable of outrunning a human at a factor of 1.5, can be issued commands at a long range from a registered PAN, has an enhanced sense of hearing and 'smell' capable of tracking humans. dog rigs have a [[Athletics]] score of 5 with a moderate training in Brawl. A dog causes 7 puncturing damage per success on it's attacks.

!!__Hawk__
!!!!Has AI II, Has Hardpoints II, Communication II (increase iii), Movement Via Medium III -- 95 SC

A ''Hawk'' is a quick, agile, and small airborne rig capable of flight akin to a conventional airplane. They posses two hardpoints for modular systems, which can range from a limited use weapons system to a sensory apparatus. They are capable of following a pre-determined flight path determined by a registered PAN at a long range. Hawks are commonly use for reconnaissance or for the delivery of goods or digital payloads across cities.

!!__Skeeter__
!!!!Has AI II, Has Hardpoints I, Puppet I(increase iii), Has Speed I, Enhanced Movement I, Has Sense I -- 60

''Skeeters'' are used across a variety of industries but also for leisure or sport. A low-end skeeter is capable of l slow fight in confined spaces and has the ability to hover in place. This and their small size has made them useful for reconnaissance and as airborne weapons platforms for small arms. They only have one hardpoint, so users PAN registered owners, whom could puppet the drone via Heads-up-display or via interfacing over a long range, have to typically choose one use over the other. Each skeeter is already fitted with a camera capable of transmitting grainy black-and-white video to it's user.

!!__Spider__
!!!!Has AI II, Has Hardpoints II, Puppet I(increase iii), Has Movement II, Enhanced Movement I, Has Sense II x3 -- 78

''Spiders'' are robust rigs so-named after their ability to hand and climb on walls and most surfaces. They are fitted with integrated senses of balance, sight and hearing on par with a natural human. They are able to be controlled via a heads-up-display unit or via interfacing. They can be controlled over a long range in this manner. They have two hard points capable of using two small arms or equipment or one large arm or equipment.








Short for '"Services and Insurance Numerical Identification", ''~SaIN ID'' is a unique numerical identifier for an individual by [[The Texaplex]] and other megacity governments. [[Megacorporations]] use the ~SaIN ID as a means of data tracking and require that any [[PAN|The Net]] accessing their systems be registered using a ~SaIN ID. The only places on the net that don’t require a ~SaIN ID are collectively referred to as [[ShadowNets]], hotbeds of criminal and jobber activity and deal making.

Being without a ~SaIN ID is difficult, but not impossible. They are self-registered and have self-identifying check to verify that they are internally consistent. The better the forgery of a ~SaIN ID the greater scrutiny it can withstand before detection and the better access to public goods and services it can provide. The best ~SaIN ID is one that belonged to a real person, but whose public and corporate records have been altered in the primary and digital back-ups. However, magnetic back-ups are often used to create permanent record keeping.

Additionally, financial corporations and bancorps are required to link and authenticate all funds and transactions with ~SaIN IDs in accordance with corporate and federal law. If a PAN is established, it is important to protect the ~SaIN ID associated with your PAN since a lot of personally identifiable information becomes associated with that ~SaIN ID. Most PAN come protected with difficult to overcome methods of encryptions and protections. 

Finally, a ~SaIN ID is registered using and certified to any cyberware legal purchased and implanted. criminal or specialized doctors that do unregistered implants are called ripper docs and operate dark boutiques.

~SaIN IDs are ranked on a C to AA status. Consult the following table to help determine the sort of access the ~SaIN ID might have, unless specifically stated when bought or created.

||<| !Rating |<|<|<|<|<|
|~|~| AA | A | BB | B | CC | C |
| !Service | Death/Estate | x | x | x |  |  |  |
|~| Health | x | x |  |  |  |  |
|~| Health+ | x |  |  |  |  |  |
|~| Public Transport | x | x | x | x | x |  |
|~| Private Transport | x | x | x | x |  |  |
|~| Voting | x | x | x |  |  |  |


!!Burning ~SaIN IDs

A jobber or blackmarket rep will burn at least one ~SaIN ID during their career. The foolish will either use their real ~SaIN ID or die without an immediate back-up. When you burn a ~SaIN ID, it means that it is no longer usable for criminal organizations and that it can be linked back to you, it’s user. As such, you typically lose all funds, Net access, contracts, PAN and technology registered using the ~SaIN ID. [[Cyberware]] will need to be refabricated to replace the ~SaIN ID registered to the implant. A failure in refabricating may lead to the destructive loss of the cyberware. Using a burned ~SaIN ID leaves you vulnerable to tracking leaves you as a possible target for enemies or a [[Jobber]] team of registered bounty hunters.

Control burns occur whenever someone burns your ~SaIN ID without your knowledge or authority. This happens typically to stop you from being connected to another person typically the person who triggered the control burn. Some burns occur however to stop a person from escaping or moving or having access to their linked [[Nova Kredits]], digital gear and services. Burns are expensive and tricky to pull off. So someone must have a good reason or too many resources to activate a control burn.








<<<
"All of man's work is a bloody business. That fact, today, is considered foolish, affairs are finished cleverly with words alone, and jobs that require effort are avoided."

-Yamamoto Tsunetomo, Hagakure, Chapter 1
<<<

```
//Merc, Gunner, Ronin, Boomer, Slab, Tanks, Muscle, Bears, Metal-Jackets, Sergeant, Castle, Brute//
```

Characters belonging to this archetype are cybered-out warriors on the hard streets of violence.  These fighters, be thugs or soldiers, use the biggest, baddest, hardest hitting weapons for the job.  Whatever you call them, they are the meanest mercenaries for higher.  However, the only thing that stops a samurai from killing all in their path is their honor.  A personal and fragged version of a Bushido code binding them to the person that pays them, or to those they are indebted to until the job is done.  Samurai will follow this code of conduct, especially when they must decide what jobs they will take. 

!!![[Abilities]] and [[Foci]]
Choose one ability array from below:

| 5 | !Athletics | 5 |
| 3 | !Charm | 2 |
| 4 | !Coersive | 3 |
| 4 | !Cool | 4 |
| 5 | !Coordination | 4 |
| 3 | !Empathy | 4 |
| 4 | !Hearty | 5 |
| 2 | !Luck | 3 |
| 3 | !Smarts | 3 |
| 4 | ! Perception | 4 |

Choose one array from below for the ranking of your character's foci:

| Dodge | !Expert | Brawl |
| Heavy Weapons |~| Heavy Weapons |
| Brawl | !Moderate | Dodge |
| Case |~| Light Weapons |
| Drive |~| Provoke |
| Run |~| Run |
| Security |~| Security |
| Kill Switch | !Basic | Run |
| Light Weapons |~| Stunts |
| Provoke |~| Wipe |

!!!Typical Equipment
*Armored Jacket; 
*Large Weapon
*Brawling Weapons
*Armoring cyberware
*pain resisting drugs
*Endurance enhancements
*explosives
*tactical-information or guides
*motorbike
*physical restraints

[[Exploits]]

!!!!Additional Cyberware
Your maximum [[Renegade Score]] and renegade score are both increased by 15.

!!!!Keep on Keeping on
If you take damage and do not have enough [[SP|Style Points]] to reduce the damage, roll Hearty. If the total damage is less than the sum of the results of all the dice, you loose all SP but take no harm. The burn increases by 1 for each time this Exploit is used until SP is regained between story act. 

!!!!Double Wammy
If you wield two of the similar type of weapons when you attack, spend 5 SP to gain strong Edge on the attack.

!!!!Stick in the Face
You suffer no penalty for shooting a target in close combat or immediate range with a heavy gun.

!!!!Break in says-a-me
You have strong edge when you roll to break an entry point or wall.

!!!!One in the Chamber
Whenever you attack and only have one bullet left in your gun or one limited use left, roll Luck. With two successes, you do not consume the last ammo or use left.

!!!!Mean Mugging
Spend 5 style and you can roll using Athletics when attempting to intimidate a person if you say no words.






[[Block Generation|F: Block Generation]]: Step 2

This step may be hectic, but you'll be generating names of things or people that you will be using in the following steps.

In this step go around the table asking for proper nouns. Names of places, things, or people should be constantly spoken. The group should speak and write each one down collectively, letting every player hear and spin off each other. If there is a popular band in the area, say it. If there’s a cool name, say it. It there’s a Corp, or a gang, or a group, say it. It doesn’t even need to be perfectly reasonable. Two Toes, say it. Black Hammer, say it. Mt. Garbage, say it. 

This step is all about coming up with evocative names, and if a strong idea pops in your idea about what they are, say it as well, but also write it down. 


```
NOTE TO THE GM
If you feel a lul or a stop come to the proper nouns, throw out what you want a proper noun for. This could be corporations, ShadowBizs, roads, clubs and scenes, stores, public figures, celebrities, music. Once you have a good list, roughly 5-7 proper nouns for each player, move onto the next step.
```







In response to circumventing [[megacorporation|Megacorporations]] control over [[The Net]] and a loss of some anonymity, various shadownets have been established by [[Tekeds]] and [[Cowboys]] to facilitate illegal and blacke market business. Of course it’s illegal and against the majority of interests of the corporations, but the shadownets continue to persist. Each shadownet is operated by a NetOperator who manages the shadownet day and night, typically a former jobber. Some shadownets are operated by criminal gangs and societies in the interest of not tripping any legal alarms.

In little detail, shadownets function as virtual networks, directories and exchanges, directing communication between parties anonymously and without the need of ~NetAccess contracts besides the shadownet’s. This helps to preserve anonymity for those between the cracks. Here, most jobbers are matched by fixers to jobs, have access to resources to launder or fence digital goods and currency. Given their benefits but also their legal status, shadownets are hard to find, and function on an invitation basis only. In fact, the only way to gain access to a shadownet is to have someone send you the introductory package for that region from the shadowNet, and only if the sender has privileges to do so. Once a jobber has a high enough [[Street Cred]], they'll eventual receive the invite, especially if they are tech savvy.







Short hand for "simulated stimuli," ''~SimStim'' is a technology that records and allows people to experience false brain stimuli as a part of a live broadcast or a prerecorded cassette. Persons can be implanted or fitted with a simstim rig has their senses, memories, and experiences recorded to be shared by others. This is a popular format for modern entertainment, but it has alternative uses as well. ~SimStim was also adopted for use in [[VR|Virtual Reality]] as a means of operating a computer terminal or deck, or playing video games.

Due to the direct stimulation and partial control of the brain by electronics, simstims have become known to become habit forming and industry boards have been created to conform all legitimate simstims to their safety standards. the major safety features are the hypnagogic block, which inhibits the conscious control body, and the associative guard, which inhibits the brain from mapping the experiences of the simstim as your own at the cost of limitations on the pleasures and escapism that simstim provides it's users.

!!~SimStars
There exists an entire industry which records, edits and produces the experience simstim "actors" called ''~SimStars'' that experience "authentic" adventures or luxuriant indulgences on behalf of the general populace. A simstar is often a person with sensitive senses since the simstim user will will experience everything the recording simstar touches, sees, hears, smells, tastes and feels. Production teams can reduce the sensations of the simstar's sensorium, but cannot easily or cheaply add to it.

Since roughly one fifth of users experience some discomfort experiencing the senses of an opposing sex or gender, some simstim production house have broadcasts and lines that use more androgynous stars.

!!Dreamscapes
People have begone applying simstim technology to the unconscious experience. ''Dreamscapes'' is an art form and style activity akin to music. It's artists are people able to sink into their subconscious to bring strange and emotionally charged dream-like experiences into the conscious mind so that they can be recorded. Producers take the raw dream and pare it down into a manageable and easy to consume experience. Dreamscapes are often metaphorical and otherworldly experiences but recent technological developments allows for some lucidity for the user in some dreamscapes.

Dreamscapes are composed and played for many purposes, ranging from aesthetic pleasure, entertainment products for the mass markets, but also religious or spiritual ceremonies or purposes. No dreamscapes have yet to be broadcasted live, but a street culture has begun where groups will experience dreamscapes and live mixes of the dreamscapes directed by a dream jockey as a group.

!!~BlkStims
A black market for simstims that have their safety limits reduced or removed are available in all cities. These modified simstim cassettes and broadcasts do not conform to safety guidelines. Extended use of these or ''~BlkStims'' can lead to a repeat user to associate the recordings with their actual personality and memory. Those mostly addicted often form groups and perform extreme and sometimes dangerous surgery and cybernetic implants to achieve a ‘perfect’ likeness of a particular simstim star, character or personality.

There are also black market simstims call ''Cut-ins'' that act as a filter or inhibitor that alters the neurological processing of the user’s brain. These cut-ins can do everything from heightening and increasing the sensory experience to overhauling or changing the user’s personality and behaviors. These cut ins usually burnout soon and force specific neural pathways and brain chemistry, leading to cycles of dependency. The now addicted cutters now require stronger and less safe cut-ins as all normal experiences become under stimulating.






''Smarts'' is a measure of a character’s memory, knowledge, trivia, cognition and analytical intelligences.  Example actions include using logic, identifying technical or esoteric items, references or ideas, and when investigating for clues.  Games of skill or strategy also focus on the use of smarts. Characters with excellent memories, are able to reason their way out of problems or are technologically savvy have high Smarts scores.






Before and during play you will earn or be rewarded with [[Street Cred]] that can be spent in a variety of ways to improve your character's resources and skills. While SC can be spent virtually any time, it will naturally be spent between games or after jobs and missions. Additionally, there are special rules for spending SC during character creation and before playing with them. these differences will be details at the end of each section.

!!![[Abilities]]
The cost of improving an [[Ability|Abilities]] once is equal to the new value after improvement. You can only improve an ability once at a time. If you would like to improve it more than once, you much purchase each increase one at a time.

You cannot increase an Ability to greater than 7, and cannot modify an Ability to greater than 9 naturally or through the use of drugs. You must use cyberware or their variants to improve an Ability via a Modified Ability Score to 10 or greater.

!!![[Foci]]
The cost of increasing a foci's ranking is described in the following table. Like with abilities, you can increase them multiple times, but must do the improvement one at a time. You cannot have more than 3 foci at Expert rank at the end of character creation.

|!Cost |!From |!To |
|5 |Untrained |Basic |
|7 |Basic |Moderate |
|//12// |//Untrained// |//Moderate// |
|13 |Moderate |Expert |
|//20// |//Basic// |//Expert// |
|//25// |//Untrained// |//Expert// |


!!![[Gear]]
Gear is the main way for your character to surpass their natural abilities, and the gear  character has a great effect on defining what they can and how they can do and how they do what they do. Each gear has it's own descriptive text that details how it functions, but each item has broad openly defined incidental effects that aren't purchased. 

The [[Gear Catalog]] provides a list of gear that is typical for those pulling jobs in the Biz.  Such items are provided in detail at the beginning of the section on gear.  If you are more experienced, feel free to use the rules found in the [[Gear Creation]] section. Each item of gear has a SC cost associated with having access to the item, or for using it over the long term. It is assumed that your character restocks, reacquires and maintains the gear they have at the start of every job.

During character creation, The SC cost of items/gear listed under typical equipment section of your character’s starting archetype costs 7/10ths of its usual rate. After character creation, you can exchange your gear at a similar rate for Street Cred to spend on.

Gear after character creation must be explained via the narrative. For example, your character cannot just suddenly use a 16th century cannon unless it was explained during play.  Contacts serve as an important means of acquiring gear, especially cyberware or illegal gear.
The more generic the gear the more likely you are to be able to buy it off a street vendor or on the market.  In these cases, contacts can help you get a better deal than usual.

!!![[Contacts]]
{{Contacts}}

!!![[Exploits]]
The cost of an Exploit is 10 SC unless a cost is listed next to the Exploits name. You can only purchase an Exploit included in your starting archetype during character creation, and more than half of your Exploits must be from your starting archetype. You cannot purchase an exploit more than once, even if it is listed in multiple [[Character Archetypes]]








Street Cred (SC) is currency pool that represents both monetary currency like the [[Nova Kredits]] or the Japanese Yen and social currency like favors or social clout. You influence others, acquire gear or safe houses, increase foci ratings, invest in your contacts, and call favors all by spending Street Cred. In the Texaplex, your Street Cred is also how the movers and the shakers in your game evaluate your character's abilities and may not even notice or speak to your character until they have spent enough SC. Since SC is not just money, your characters everyday expectations do not effect your SC. Only important or possibly dramatic //purchases// cost SC.

See [[Earning Street Cred]] on how to earn SC and see [[Spending Street Cred]] on how to spend it.






When you look this good going it, it doesn’t matter that it is.  Those living in the 20 minutes past the dark future still haven’t forgotten the importance of style, or having a personal brand identity.  It doesn’t matter so much what you do, but who knows it and who’s talking about it.  Morality has become a fashion choice, a way to earn social currency, or street cred, with those you are out to impress.

Quick snappy decisions about who someone is and what they do and believe are important whenever the next person you meet is packing heat or knows the quickest way to bleed you dry.  Always keep an eye out for those with a style different than yours. They might just kill you because of it - especially if your style matches those who would kill them.







<<<
If you can’t do it with style, you might as well not try.

//- Rug Burn//
<<<

Your character is intended to do cool and impressive things, to shrug off bullets, accomplish impossible tasks, circumvent obstacles, notice things that no one else does, and be bad ass.  ''Style Points'' (SP or Style) are your way of making those things happen. They represent in one value what other games might represent as multiple values or points. SP are your hit points, shields, points spent to control the narrative, re-roll dice, gain [[Edge]], reduce [[Burn]], and to use [[Exploits]].  SP are all these things in one.

You spend and regain Style Points over the normal course of play.

!! Spending Style Points

!!! Add Dice
Spend a number of SP equal to the number of dice that will be in the dice pool after they are bought but before [[Edge]] or [[Burn]] effect the dice pool. You can buy multiple dice, but each die must be added consecutively, one at a time.

!!! Reduce damage received. 
Spend a number of SP to reduce damage your character takes by an equal amount.

!!! Use a Skill or Gear. 
Some gear and skills allow you to use them at a cost.  Spend the Style as indicated in the skill and gears description and resolve your action as described.

!!! Additional Actions. 
During your turn you may want to do more than is normally allowed.  Spend 3 style to earn an extra reaction. Spend 3 style to improve a reaction to a quick action. Spend 6 style to improve a quick action to a complex action.  You may not take more than 1 complex action or 3 actions on a turn in this manner.

!!! Grant edge. 
You may spend style to grant your character Edge on a single dice roll. It costs 3 style to grant weak Edge, and 5 style to grant strong Edge.  You can only purchase one Edge per dice roll. In order to buy Edge, you must not suffer Burn on the dice roll.

!!! Reduce burn.  
You may spend 5 style to reduce a Burn on a single dice roll by 1.  You can reduce Burn in this manner as many times as you want on a dice roll. If you reduce burn to 0, you no longer suffer burn on the dice roll.

!!! Establish a narrative element.  
PC players can introduce narrative objects, details, and context to directly shape the narrative.  This allows for the players to add details that they want to interact with that the GM did not indicate.   For example, let’s say that the players are scrambling looking for ammo, a player could spend points and find a full magazine in their side bag or on a fallen enemy.  The GM decides whether the use is reasonable, as well as the cost of introducing the narrative element.

!!Regaining Style
Characters regain Style after the completion of certain events during play. The most common means of regaining SP is through rolling the dice. A character regains 1 SP for every die that shares a value with another dice. Crack Jaw kicks down the door and unloads all barrels of their Patriot Tri-Barrel into the closest mook. They roll 2, 3, 3, 7 & 7.  So they regain 4 style, 2 from the two 3s and another 2 from the two 7s.

The most formal way of regaining experience is when you buy new gear or clothing, when you rest long enough, or when you start a new story.  These methods of regaining style typically increase your style points to maximum. If ever there is a time where character isn't taking heat or right now would be a good moment for a montage of a movie where the character is kitting out before heading out, you most likely should be regaining at least half your style points spent.

!!! Variant: //Group Reward//
Other less formal ways of regaining style include when you complete a stylish or impressive action, whenever all the other players think what you did was cool, when you spout off a quippy one-liner that sounds like it came from a 1980s or 1990s action film, or whenever the GM says so.  These less formal ways of regaining SP only allow players to gain a small but effective amount.  The amount of any SP regained is determined by the GM but should accurately reflect in game terms just how cool the table thinks the PC was.
